subdivision or a local authority thereof.

### Article 19
**Professors, Teachers and Researchers**

A professor, teacher or researcher who makes a temporary visit to a Contracting
State for a period not exceeding 2 years for the purpose of teaching or conducting
research at a university, college, school, or other similar educational institution,
and who is, or immediately before such visit was, a resident of the other
Contracting State shall be exempt from tax in the first-mentioned Contracting
State in respect of remuneration from such teaching or research.

### Article 20
**Students and Trainees**

Payments which a student or business trainee who is or was immediately before
visiting a Contracting State a resident of the other Contracting State and who is
present in the first-mentioned State solely for the purpose of his education or
training receives for the purpose of his maintenance, education or training shall
not be taxed in that State, provided that such payments arise from sources outside
that State.

### Article 22
### Capital

1.  Capital represented by immovable property referred to in Article 6, owned by a resident of a Contracting State and situated in the other Contracting State may be taxed in that other State.

3.  Capital of an enterprise of a Contracting State represented by ships and aircraft operated in international traffic and by movable property pertaining to the operation of such ships and aircraft shall be taxable only in that Contracting State.
4.  All other elements of capital of a resident of a Contracting State shall be taxable only in that State.

<header>
Kuwait Today / Al-Kuwait Al-Youm <orig>الكويت اليوم</orig> Issue 1738 Seventy-First Year 128

</header>
  It is agreed that double taxation shall be avoided in accordance with the following paragraphs of this Article:
    a) In the case of Kuwait
        Where a resident of Kuwait derives income or capital, in accordance with the provisions of this Agreement, may be taxed in both Kuwait and San Marino. Kuwait shall allow as a deduction from the tax on the income or capital of that resident, an amount equal to the income or capital tax paid in San Marino.

        Such deduction in either case shall not, however, exceed that part of the tax on income or capital, as computed before the deduction is given, which is attributable, as the case may be, to the income or capital, which may be taxed in San Marino.

    b) In the case of San Marino
        Where a resident of San Marino owns items of income or capital which are taxable in Kuwait, San Marino, in determining its tax on income or capital specified in Article 2 of this Agreement, may exclude in the basis upon which such taxes are imposed the said items of income or capital, unless specific provisions of this Agreement otherwise provide.

        In such case, San Marino shall deduct from the taxes so calculated the tax on income or capital paid in Kuwait, but in an amount not exceeding that proportion of the aforesaid San Marino tax, which such items of income or capital bear to the entire income or capital.

## Article 24
### Non-Discrimination

1. Nationals of a Contracting State shall not be subjected in the other Contracting
State to any taxation or any requirement connected therewith which is other or
more burdensome than the taxation and connected requirements to which
nationals of that other State in the same circumstances, in particular with respect
to residence, are or may be subjected.
2. The taxation on a permanent establishment, which an enterprise of a Contracting
State has in the other Contracting State, shall not be less favourably levied in that
other State than the taxation levied on enterprises of that other State carrying on
the same activities in the same circumstances. This provision shall not be
construed as obliging a Contracting State to grant to residents of the other
Contracting State any personal allowances, reliefs, and reductions for taxation

In paragraph 6 of Article 12, apply, interest, royalties and other disbursements paid by an enterprise of a Contracting State to a resident of the other Contracting State shall, for the purpose of determining the taxable profits of such enterprise, be deductible under the same conditions as if they had been paid to a resident of the first-mentioned State.

4. Enterprises of a Contracting State, the capital of which is wholly or partly owned or controlled directly or indirectly, by one or more residents of the other Contracting State, shall not be subjected in the first-mentioned State to any taxation or any requirement connected therewith which is other or more burdensome than the taxation and connected requirements to which other similar enterprises the capital of which is wholly or partly owned or controlled directly or indirectly by one or more residents of the first-mentioned State or of any third state are or may be subjected.

5. Nothing in this Article shall be interpreted as imposing a legal obligation on a Contracting State to extend to the residents of the other Contracting State the benefit of any treatment, preference or privilege which may be accorded to any third state or its residents by virtue of the formation of a customs union, common market, a free trade area or any regional or sub-regional arrangement relating wholly or mainly to taxation or investment of capital in which such the first-mentioned State may be a party.

6. The provisions of this Article shall, notwithstanding the provisions of Article 2, apply to taxes of every kind and description.

  "document_date": "2025-05-11",

  "publisher": "Kuwait Today / Al-Kuwait Al-Youm <orig>الكويت اليوم</orig>",
  "page_summary": "This page details Article 25, the Mutual Agreement Procedure, outlining the process for resolving taxation issues between contracting states, including time limits for presenting cases and the role of competent authorities in reaching satisfactory solutions and eliminating double taxation."
}
</page_metadata>
<header>
Kuwait Today / Al-Kuwait Al-Youm <orig>الكويت اليوم</orig> Issue No. 1738 Seventy-First Year 131
Sunday 13 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1446 AH 11/5/2025 AD
</header>
  Where a person considers that the actions of one or both of the Contracting States result or will result for him in taxation not in accordance with the provisions of this Agreement, he may, irrespective of the remedies provided by the domestic law of those States, present the case to the competent authority of either Contracting State. The case must be presented within 3 years from the first notification of the action resulting in taxation not in accordance with the provisions of the Agreement.
2.  The competent authority shall endeavour if the objection appears to it to be justified and if it is not itself able to arrive at a satisfactory solution, to resolve the case by mutual agreement with the competent authority of the other Contracting State, with a view to the avoidance of taxation which is not in accordance with the Agreement. Any agreement reached shall be implemented notwithstanding any time limits in the domestic law of the Contracting States.
3.  The competent authorities of the Contracting States shall endeavour to resolve by mutual agreement any difficulties or doubts arising as to the interpretation or application of the Agreement. They may also consult together for the elimination of double taxation in cases not provided for in the Agreement.
4.  The competent authorities of the Contracting States may communicate with each other directly, including through a joint commission consisting of themselves or their representatives, for the purpose of reaching an agreement in the sense of the preceding paragraphs.

  The competent authorities of the Contracting States shall exchange such information as is foreseeably relevant for carrying out the provisions of this Agreement or to the administration or enforcement of the domestic laws concerning taxes of every kind and description imposed on behalf of the Contracting States, or of their political subdivisions or local authorities, insofar as the taxation thereunder is not contrary to the Agreement. The exchange of information is not restricted by Articles 1 and 2.
2.  Any information received under paragraph 1 by a Contracting State shall be treated as secret in the same manner as information obtained under the domestic laws of that State and shall be disclosed only to persons or authorities (including courts and administrative) concerned with the assessment or collection of, the enforcement or prosecution in respect of, or the determination of appeals in relation to the taxes referred to in paragraph 1, or the oversight of the above. Such persons or authorities shall use the information only for such purposes. They may disclose the information in public court proceedings or in judicial decisions. Notwithstanding the foregoing, information received by a Contracting State may be used for other purposes when such information may be used for such other purposes under the laws of both States and the competent authority of the supplying State authorizes such use.
3.  In no case shall the provisions of paragraphs 1 and 2 be construed so as to impose on a Contracting State the obligation:
    a) to carry out administrative measures at variance with the laws and administrative practice of that or of the other Contracting State;
    b) to supply information which is not obtainable under the laws or in the normal course of the administration of that or of the other Contracting State;

### Article 29
### Limiting On Benefits

Notwithstanding any provisions of this Agreement, a benefit under this Agreement shall not be granted in respect of an item of income or capital if it is reasonable to conclude, having regard to all relevant facts and circumstances, that obtaining that benefit was one of the principal purposes of any arrangement or transaction that resulted directly or indirectly in that benefit, unless it is established that granting that benefit in these circumstances would be in accordance with the object and purpose of the relevant provisions of this Agreement.

### Article 30
### Entry Into Force

Each of the Contracting States shall notify the other of the completion of its constitutional procedures for the entry into force of this Agreement. This Agreement shall enter into force on the date of the later of these notifications and its provisions shall thereupon have effect in both Contracting States:
a) With respect to taxes withheld, to the amounts collected as from 1 January of the calendar year next following that in which this Agreement enters into force; and

## Article 31
### Duration and Termination

This Agreement shall remain in force until terminated by a Contracting State.
Either Contracting State may terminate the Agreement, not earlier than 5 years
from the entry into force, through diplomatic channels, by giving notice of
termination at least 6 months before the end of the calendar year; in any time
before the expiry of any subsequent period or periods of 5 years. In such event,
the Agreement shall cease to have effect:

a) with respect to taxes withheld, to the amounts collected as from 1 January of
the calendar year next following that in which the notification of termination
is given; and

b) with respect to the other taxes on income or capital, to the taxes referred to
taxable periods as from 1 January of the calendar year next following that in
which the notification of termination is given.

# Decree No. 79 of 2025
## Replacing Article (45) of the Decree Issued on
## 4 April 1979 Regarding the Civil Service System <orig>نظام الخدمة المدنية</orig>

*   Having reviewed the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig>,
*   And the Amiri Order <orig>الأمر الأميري</orig> issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 AH corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
*   And Decree-Law No. 15 of 1979 regarding the Civil Service <orig>الخدمة المدنية</orig>, and its amending laws,
*   And the Decree issued on 7 Jumada al-Ula 1399 AH corresponding to 4 April 1979 regarding the Civil Service System <orig>نظام الخدمة المدنية</orig>, and its amending decrees,
*   And Decree No. 84 of 2024 regarding Ministerial Succession and Delegations <orig>الحلول والإنابات الوزارية</orig>, and its amending decrees,
*   And upon the proposal of the Civil Service Council <orig>مجلس الخدمة المدنية</orig> at its meeting No. (4) held on 6/6/2024,
*   And based on the submission of the Deputy Prime Minister <orig>نائب رئيس مجلس الوزراء</orig> and Minister of State for Cabinet Affairs <orig>وزير الدولة لشئون مجلس الوزراء</orig>,
*   And after the approval of the Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>,

We have decreed the following:
### Article One
The text of Article (45) of the aforementioned Decree regarding the Civil Service System <orig>نظام الخدمة المدنية</orig> shall be replaced with the following text:
#### Article (45):
((Without prejudice to Article (39) of this System, the Minister <orig>الوزير</orig> may grant an employee <orig>الموظف</orig> special leave <orig>إجازة خاصة</orig> that is not deducted from their regular leave balance <orig>رصيد إجازاته الدورية</orig> to accompany a patient whose treatment abroad has been approved by the Ministry of Health <orig>وزارة الصحة</orig>, along with an escort, for the period determined for the case at the beginning of each month. This period may be extended for a maximum of six months without pay)).

### Article Two
The Ministers <orig>الوزراء</orig> - each within their respective jurisdiction - shall implement this Decree, which shall be effective from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>.

The Paris Declaration on the International Solar Alliance <orig>التحالف الدولي للطاقة الشمسية</orig> issued on 30 November 2015, and the shared ambition to achieve the joint efforts required to reduce the cost of financing and the cost of technology, and to mobilize more than 1000 billion US dollars in investments required by 2030 for the widespread deployment of solar energy, and to pave the way for future technologies that adapt to needs,

And recognizing that solar energy provides developing countries with solar energy resources, located wholly or partially within the Tropics of Cancer and Capricorn, an unprecedented opportunity to achieve prosperity, energy security, and sustainable development for their peoples,

And recognizing the specific and common obstacles that still hinder the rapid and massive expansion of solar energy in these countries,

We affirm that these obstacles can be addressed through consistent cooperation among countries rich in solar energy resources, with a strong and resolute political impetus, and that better coordination and aggregation of demand for solar energy financing, technologies, innovation, or capacity building across countries will lead to the achievement of this goal, and that providing training programs to secure cost-effective and high-quality solutions, and to provide reliable and affordable solar energy accessible to all,

Motivated by their desire to establish an effective tool for coordination and decision-making among themselves,

Have agreed as follows:

# Article Two
## Guiding Principles
1. Members shall take independent actions through voluntarily launched programs and activities, which aim to better coordinate and aggregate demand for, among other things, solar energy financing, solar energy technologies, innovation, research and development, and capacity building.
2. In this regard, Members shall cooperate closely and seek to establish mutually beneficial relationships with relevant organizations and stakeholders in both the public and private sectors, and with non-member states.
3. Each Member shall participate and crystallize updates for those solar applications for which it seeks to obtain collective action under the International Solar Alliance <orig>التحالف الدولي للطاقة الشمسية</orig>. On a common analytical basis, solar energy applications shall be mapped, including the relevant information for their models, objectives, impact, and possible initiatives implemented or planned for the application of these objectives, and technologies along the value chain and promotion of deployment. The Secretariat shall maintain a database of these assessments to highlight the potential for cooperation.
4. Each Member shall serve as a focal point and cell for the International Solar Alliance <orig>التحالف الدولي للطاقة الشمسية</orig>, forming a permanent network of International Solar Alliance <orig>التحالف الدولي للطاقة الشمسية</orig> correspondents in Member States. They shall interact with each other, as well as with relevant stakeholders, to identify areas of common interest, design program proposals, and submit recommendations to the Secretariat regarding the implementation of the objectives of this Alliance.

  The program of the International Solar Alliance <orig>التحالف الدولي للطاقة الشمسية</orig> includes a set of measures, projects, and activities
    that members are required to undertake with the assistance of the Secretariat in an organized manner, in furtherance of the objectives
    and guiding principles mentioned in Articles One and Two. The program has been designed to ensure
    maximum synergy and participation of the largest possible number of members, and it includes simple and measurable actions.
2.  Program proposals are designed through direct consultations among all National Focal Points,
    with the assistance of the Secretariat, and based on information awaited by the members. A program proposal may be submitted
    by any two members, a group of members, or by the Secretariat. The Secretariat ensures consistency
    and coordination among all programs of the International Solar Alliance <orig>التحالف الدولي للطاقة الشمسية</orig>.
3.  Program proposals are officially circulated by the Secretariat to the Assembly, through the network of National Focal Points.
    A program proposal is open for accession by interested members if
    it is supported by at least two members and not subject to objections from more than five
4.  A program proposal is officially adopted by interested members through a joint declaration.
    The members participating in the program shall determine all procedures related to the implementation of the program, which shall be
    carried out under the guidance and with the assistance of the Secretariat, by country representatives appointed by each member.
5.  The annual work plan provides an overview of the programs and other activities of the International Solar Alliance <orig>التحالف الدولي للطاقة الشمسية</orig>.
    This plan is presented by the General Secretariat to the Assembly, ensuring that
    all programs and activities of the annual work plan fall within the overall objective of the International Solar Alliance <orig>التحالف الدولي للطاقة الشمسية</orig> standards.

# Article Four
## The Assembly

1.  The Parties shall establish an Assembly, in which each member shall be represented, to make decisions regarding its
    administrative structure and the organized procedures to be taken to define its objective. The Assembly shall meet annually on

The Assembly may also convene in

## General Conditions

1.  Ministerial level, by a decision of the International Solar Alliance <orig>التحالف الدولي للطاقة الشمسية</orig>. The Assembly may also convene under special circumstances.
2.  Mini-sessions of the Assembly shall be held to evaluate programs at the ministerial level and make decisions regarding their continued implementation, in furtherance of Article 3.7.
3.  The Assembly shall assess the overall impact of programs and other activities within the framework of the International Solar Alliance <orig>التحالف الدولي للطاقة الشمسية</orig>, particularly in terms of solar energy deployment, performance, reliability, as well as cost and funding volume. Based on this assessment, members shall take all necessary decisions regarding the continued implementation of the Alliance's objective.
4.  The Assembly shall take all necessary decisions regarding the functioning of the International Solar Alliance <orig>التحالف الدولي للطاقة الشمسية</orig>, including the selection of the Director-General and the approval of the operational budget.
5.  Each member shall have one vote in the Assembly. Observers and partner organizations may participate without voting rights. Decisions on procedural matters shall be taken by a simple majority of members present and voting. Decisions on substantive matters shall be taken by a two-thirds majority of members present and voting. Members participating in a specific program shall take decisions related to that program.
6.  All decisions taken by the International Steering Committee of the International Solar Alliance <orig>التحالف الدولي للطاقة الشمسية</orig>, established under the Paris Declaration on the International Alliance issued on November 30, 2015, shall be submitted to the Assembly for adoption at its first meeting.

## Constituent Committee

### Secretariat

1.  The Parties shall establish a Secretariat to assist them in their collective work under this Agreement. The Secretariat shall consist of a Director-General, a Chief Executive Officer, and other staff as needed.
2.  The Director-General shall be elected by the Assembly and shall be accountable to it for a term of four years, renewable once.

The Director General is responsible to the Assembly for the appointment of staff, the organization and functioning of the Secretariat, as well as for resource mobilization.
4. The General Secretariat prepares matters for the work of the Assembly and implements decisions assigned to it by the Council. It ensures that appropriate steps are taken to implement the Assembly's decisions and coordinates the actions of members in implementing such decisions. The Secretariat, among other things, shall:
a) Assist national focal points in developing program proposals and recommendations submitted to the Assembly.
b) Provide guidance and support to members in the implementation of each program, including fundraising.
c) Act on behalf of the Assembly, or on behalf of a group of members participating in a specific program, when requested to do so, and in particular establish contacts with relevant stakeholders.
d) Develop and qualify all comprehensive communication means, tools, and activities necessary for the operation of this Alliance and its programs, as approved by the Assembly.

### Article Six
### Budget and Financial Resources

1. The operating costs of the Secretariat and the Assembly, and all costs related to support functions and comprehensive activities, constitute the budget of the Alliance, which is covered by:
a) Voluntary contributions from member partner states, the United Nations and its agencies, and other states.
b) Voluntary donations from the private sector; in the event of a potential conflict of interest, the Secretariat shall refer the matter to the Assembly for approval of the acceptance of assistance.
c) Revenues generated from specific activities approved by the Assembly.
2. The Secretariat shall organize proposals before the General Assembly for the establishment and funding of a fund for collecting money from the Alliance's budget revenues, with an initial allocation of 26 million US dollars.

The Government of India contributed USD 27 million to the Alliance for the establishment of a Corpus Fund, and for building recurring infrastructure and facilities over five years from 2016-2017 to 2020-2021. In addition, public sector undertakings of the Government of India, namely the Solar Energy Corporation of India (SECI) and the Indian Renewable Energy Development Agency (IREDA), each pledged a contribution of USD 1 million for the establishment of a fund affiliated with the Alliance.
4. The financial resources required for the implementation of a specific program, other than administrative costs falling within the budget submitted by the states participating in this program, shall be assessed with the support and assistance of the Secretariat.
5. External entities may be engaged for the financial and administrative activities of this Alliance, other than programs, to another organization, in accordance with a separate agreement determined by the Assembly.
6. The Secretariat, within the Assembly's budget, may appoint an external auditor to audit the accounts of the International Solar Alliance <orig>التحالف الدولي للطاقة الشمسية</orig>.

## Article Seven
### Member State Status

3. Membership is open to United Nations member states. These states become members of this Alliance by signing this Agreement and submitting an instrument of ratification, acceptance, or approval.

## Article Eight
### Partner Organization

1. The Assembly may grant partner organization status to organizations capable of assisting this Alliance in achieving its objectives, including regional intergovernmental economic integration organizations formed by sovereign states. At least one of these organizations must be a member of the International Solar Alliance <orig>التحالف الدولي للطاقة الشمسية</orig>.

### Article Nine
Cooperation
The Assembly may grant observer status to applicants for membership or partnership whose finances remain independent, or to any other organization that can promote the interests and objectives of the Alliance.

### Article Ten
Status, Privileges, and Immunities of the International Solar Alliance <orig>التحالف الدولي للطاقة الشمسية</orig>
1. The International Solar Alliance <orig>التحالف الدولي للطاقة الشمسية</orig> shall possess legal personality under the Host Country Agreement, and the capacity to contract, acquire and dispose of movable and immovable property, and to institute legal proceedings.
2. Under the same Host Country Agreement, the Secretariat of the Organization shall enjoy absolute privileges, such as freedom from interference, and applicable immunities that are necessary at its headquarters to independently carry out its functions and programs as approved by the Assembly.
3. Under the supervision of a member, and subject to its national regulations and in accordance with a separate agreement, if necessary; the Alliance Secretariat may enjoy such immunities and privileges as are necessary for the independent performance of its functions and programs.

### Article Eleven
Amendments and Withdrawal
1. Any member may propose amendments to the Framework Agreement.

Amendments to the Framework Agreement shall be adopted by the Assembly by a two-thirds majority of the members present and voting. The amendments shall enter into force when two-thirds of the members approve them in accordance with their respective constitutional procedures.
3. Any member may withdraw from the current Framework Agreement by giving three months' notice to the Depositary. The withdrawal shall be announced to the other members by the Depositary.

### Article Twelve
#### Headquarters of the International Solar Alliance
The headquarters of the International Solar Alliance <orig>التحالف الدولي للطاقة الشمسية</orig> shall be in India.

### Article Thirteen
#### Ratification and Entry into Force
1. The Framework Agreement shall be ratified, accepted, or approved by States in accordance with their respective constitutional procedures. This Framework Agreement shall enter into force on the thirtieth day after the date of deposit of the 35th instrument of ratification, acceptance, or approval.
2. For members who have deposited an instrument of ratification, acceptance, or approval after the entry into force of the Framework Agreement, this Framework Agreement shall enter into force on the thirtieth day after the date of deposit of the relevant instrument.
3. The International Steering Committee shall have a file for the Alliance once the International Solar Alliance <orig>التحالف الدولي للطاقة الشمسية</orig> is established.

## Article I
Programmes and other activities

A Programme of the ISA consists of actions, projects and activities to be taken in a
coordinated manner by Members, with the assistance of the Secretariat, in furtherance of the
objectives and purposes of this Agreement and in accordance with the present Agreement. It
may in particular include joint effort and participation of the largest possible number of
Members. They include single, multi-country, or regional projects.

Programmes proposals are designed through open consultations among all National Focal
Points, with the assistance of the Secretariat, and based on information provided by Members.
A Programme can be proposed by any two Members or group of Members, or by the
Secretariat. It is submitted to the Assembly for its approval by consensus.

Programme proposals are considered by the Secretariat to the Assembly by diligent scrutiny,
through the outreach of National Focal Points. A Programme proposal is deemed open to
Members for comments within 30 days. The Secretariat, at all times, must maintain and if
approved, are not acted on by members but by members.

ISA programme proposal is formally endorsed by Members, willing to join, through a Joint
Declaration of the Programme and taken by Members who are directly involved in the
implementation of the Programme. They are circulated, with the guidance and assistance of
the Secretariat, to country Representatives designated by each member.

The annual work plan gives an overview of the Programmes, and other activities of the ISA
to be presented by the Secretariat to the Assembly for its approval. The annual work plan will
consist of the annual work plan, an overview of the total activities of the ISA.

## Article IV
Assembly

The Parties hereby establish an Assembly, in which Members is represented, to make
decisions concerning the implementation of this Agreement and coordinated actions to be
taken to achieve its objectives. The Assembly meets annually at the Ministerial level at the
seat of the ISA. The Assembly may also meet under special circumstances.

Third-party sessions of the Assembly may be held in order to seek the support of the Programme in
financial terms and make decisions regarding the further implementation of the objectives
of the ISA.

The Assembly oversees the aggregate efforts of the ISA Programmes and other activities under the
supervision of the Secretariat, and performs, inter alia, reliability, as well as well as well as
open and ready of English. Based on this assessment, Members take all necessary decisions
regarding the further implementation of the objectives of the ISA.

4. The Assembly takes all necessary decisions regarding the functioning of the ISA, including
the Secretariat, the Director-General and approval of the operating budget.

## Article 32
Under the same Host Country Agreement, or any other agreement, the ISA Secretariat shall enjoy such privileges and immunities as are necessary for the independent discharge of its functions and programmes approved by the Assembly.
Any dispute concerning the interpretation or application of the Host Country Agreement, the ISA Secretariat, or any other agreement, the ISA Secretariat may apply with a Member State, shall be settled by negotiation, conciliation, or arbitration.

## Article 33
### Amendments
Any Member may propose amendments to the Framework Agreement after eight of one year from the entry into force of the Framework Agreement.
Amendments shall be adopted by the Assembly by two-thirds majority of the Members present and voting. The amendments shall enter into force when two-thirds of the Members have deposited their instruments of ratification, acceptance or approval.
Any Member that has not deposited its instrument of ratification, acceptance or approval of the amendments within three months from the present Framework Agreement, by giving a notice of three months to the Depositary, its withdrawal from such withdrawal are notified to the Depositary and circulated to Members.

## Article 35
### Signature and entry into force
1. Ratification, acceptance or approval of the Framework Agreement is effected by deposit of an instrument of ratification, acceptance or approval with the Depositary.
2. The Framework Agreement shall enter into force on the thirtieth day after the date of deposit of the fifteenth instrument of ratification, acceptance or approval.
3. For Members having deposited an instrument of ratification, acceptance or approval after the entry into force of the Framework Agreement, this Framework Agreement shall enter into force for such Members on the thirtieth day after the date of deposit of their instrument of ratification, acceptance or approval.
4. Observers ISA is established, the International Steering Committee of the ISA secretariat.

## Article 36
### Depositary, registration, authentic text
The Government of the Republic of India is the Depositary of the Framework Agreement.

## Article 37
### Withdrawal
Any Member may withdraw from the Framework Agreement by giving a notice of one year from the date of deposit of the instrument of withdrawal to the Depositary.
The withdrawal shall take effect upon the expiration of one year from the date of deposit of the instrument of withdrawal.

# Memorandum of Understanding
## Regarding the Establishment of a Joint Committee for Cooperation
### Between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of India

The Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of India (hereinafter referred to as "the Parties", and each individually referred to as "a Party"),

Recognizing the traditional ties, strong friendship, and robust connections between the Parties,

Desiring to enhance cooperation between the Parties in various fields,

And acknowledging the importance of establishing this Joint Committee for Cooperation in an effort to continue the fruitful and effective partnership between the Parties,

Have reached the following:

## Article 1
### Areas of Cooperation

1) The Parties agree to establish a Joint Committee for Cooperation, hereinafter referred to as "the Committee", to develop bilateral relations between them, and it shall be tasked with the following:
    *   (1) Exchange of information and views on professional matters, including security and police issues of mutual interest.
    *   (2) Cooperation in the fields of defense and security, cybersecurity, and counter-terrorism.
    *   (3) Economy, trade, and investment.
    *   (4) Food security, including agriculture, livestock, fisheries, and food processing.
    *   (5) Education and skills development.
    *   (6) Judicial cooperation, including labor issues and legal migration.

For the Government of the State of Kuwait
[Signature]
Minister of Foreign Affairs

For the Government of the Republic of India
[Signature]
Minister of External Affairs

2- Following up on the agreements, treaties, and cooperation programs concluded between the two Parties and working towards their full implementation in accordance with national resource frameworks, laws, regulations, and bylaws.
3- Facilitating the exchange of information, expertise, and consultations between the two Parties in the areas of cooperation mentioned in paragraph (1) of this Article.

### Article 4
### Chairperson of the Committee
1- The Committee shall be chaired by the Ministers of Foreign Affairs of the two Parties or their representatives.
2- Committee meetings shall be held in the presence of Undersecretaries of the concerned ministries in the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> or their representatives, and representatives of the concerned ministries in the Government of India <orig>حكومة الهند</orig> or their representatives at the senior official level.

### Article 5
### Time and Place of Committee Meetings
1- The Committee shall hold its ordinary session once every two (2) years in the capital of each state, alternately or exceptionally upon the request of either Party.
2- The two Parties shall agree on the dates of the Committee meeting through diplomatic channels.

  There shall be a meeting of senior officials of the Committee responsible for preparing, following up, and coordinating the Committee's meetings, and coordinating the meetings of the senior officials' meeting of the Committee, which shall be held in the same capital where the Committee's meetings are held.
2.  The meetings of the Committee of Senior Officials shall be chaired by senior officials from the Ministries of Foreign Affairs <orig>وزارتي خارجية</orig> of both countries, namely the Deputy Foreign Minister of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Secretary (CPV&DIA) at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs <orig>وزارة الخارجية</orig> of the Republic of India <orig>جمهورية الهند</orig>, provided that its membership includes representatives from the competent bodies in the fields to be discussed by the Committee in its meetings and those legitimately on its agenda.
3.  The meeting of senior officials shall convene annually, alternately in the capital of each country, and within 3 months prior to the Committee's meeting in that year.

### Article 5
## Committee's Agenda
1.  The host party shall prepare a draft agenda for the meeting and submit it to the other party at least two (2) months prior to the commencement of the Committee's meeting.
2.  The Chairperson of the Committee shall transfer the work, submit these recommendations, and include them in the minutes of the Committee's meeting.
3.  All deliberations, documents, minutes, statements, or official notes issued by the Committee shall be considered confidential and may not be circulated or published except with the written consent of both parties.

### Article 9
### Entry into Force and Termination
1. This Memorandum of Understanding shall enter into force on the date of receipt of the last written notification through diplomatic channels regarding the completion by both Parties, in accordance therewith, of their internal procedures required for its entry into force.
2. This Memorandum of Understanding shall remain in effect for a period of five (5) years, after which it shall be automatically renewed for similar periods, unless one Party notifies the other Party in writing, and through diplomatic channels, of its intention to terminate it six months prior to its expiry date.
3. The provisions of this Memorandum of Understanding shall not prejudice the laws in force in both countries or the rights or obligations of either Party arising from international treaties and agreements to which either of them is a party.
4. The termination of this Memorandum of Understanding shall not affect the validity of any separate agreements, projects, or activities concluded thereunder.

**MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING**

**ON ESTABLISHING JOINT COMMISSION FOR**

**COOPERATION BETWEEN**

**THE GOVERNMENT OF THE STATE OF KUWAIT**

**AND**

**THE GOVERNMENT OF THE REPUBLIC OF INDIA**

The Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of India
(hereinafter jointly referred to as the 'Parties' and individually as a 'Party')

Acknowledging the historical ties, traditional friendship, and strong people to people
contacts between the Parties,

Desirous of promoting cooperation between the parties in various fields,

Recognizing the importance of establishing this Joint commission for cooperation in an
effort to continue the effective and solid partnership between the two countries,

Have reached to the following understanding:

### Article 1
### Cooperation Fields

I. The Parties shall establish a Joint Commission for Cooperation, hereinafter
referred to as the "Commission", to develop bilateral relations between them. It
shall be entrusted with the following tasks:

II. Exchange of information and opinions on topics of a political nature including
regional and international issues of mutual interest.

III. Defence and security cooperation, Cyber security and counter-terrorism.

III. Economy, Trade and Investment.
IV. Food Security, including agriculture, livestock, fisheries, food-processing.
V. Education and skill development.
VI. Consular cooperation, including Labour and Legal Migration Issues.
VII. Health and pharmaceutical cooperation.
VIII. Science and technology cooperation, including space, IT & ITes, new and emerging technologies.
IX. Cultural, people to people linkages and Humanitarian cooperation.
X. UN and multilateral cooperation.
XI. Any other areas of cooperation determined by the Parties.

2. Follow up on the agreements, treaties and cooperation programs signed between the Parties, and work on their full implementation, subject to availability of resources and national Laws, Regulations & Rules.
3. Facilitate the exchange of information, experiences, and consultations between the Parties in the areas of cooperation mentioned in Paragraph (1) of this Article.

## Article 2
### Head of Commission

1. The commission shall be Chaired by the Foreign Ministers of the Parties or their respective representatives.
2. The Commission's meetings shall have the Under-Secretaries of the concerned Ministries of the State of Kuwait or their representatives and Secretaries of the concerned Ministries of the Government of India or their representatives at senior official level.

## Article 3
### Time and place of the commission

1. The commission shall hold its regular sessions once every two (2) years in the capital of each country, alternately, or exceptionally at the request of either Party.
2. The Parties shall mutually agree to set the dates for the meeting of the Commission through diplomatic channels.

### Article 4
### Senior Official's meeting (SoM)

I. There will be a SoM of the Commission that will undertake the preparation, follow-
up, and coordination of the meetings of the Commission. The meetings of the SOM will
precede the Commission's meetings and will be held in the same capital where the
Commission's meetings will be held.

II. The senior officials of the two Foreign Ministries of the two countries (Secretary
(CPV&OIA) of the Ministry of External Affairs of the Government of India and Deputy
Foreign Minister of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the State of Kuwait) will head his/her
country's delegation in the meetings of the SoM and it will include in its membership
representatives of the competent authorities in the areas that the Commission will discuss
in its meetings and listed on its agenda.

III. The SoM shall meet every year, alternately in each other's capital, and within 3 months
before the meeting of the Commission in that year.

### Article 5
### Commission Agenda

1. A draft meeting agenda will be prepared by the host Party and referred to the other
Party at least two (2) months before the start of the Commission meeting.

2. The SoM will propose /recommend the agenda. These recommendations are
compiled and included in the minutes of the Commission's meeting.

3. All deliberations, documents, minutes, statements, or official announcements
emanating from the Commission shall remain confidential and shall not be circulated or
published except with the written Agreement of the Parties.

### Article 6
### Joint Working Groups on Areas of Mutual Interest

1. In addition to the existing Joint Working Groups (JWGs) between the Parties on
Hydrocarbons, Medical Cooperation; and Manpower, Labour and Employment, new Joint
Working Groups of mutual interest in the following areas shall be set up:

I. Trade and commerce
II. Investment cooperation
III. Education and skill development

Science and Technology

2. The JWGs will report to the Commission through the SoM, and will ordinarily hold
their meetings before the Commission and the SoM meetings.

### Article 7
### Dispute settlement

Any dispute/disagreement arising out of the application and/or interpretation of this MOU
shall be settled amicably through diplomatic channels and through consultations or
negotiations between the Parties.

### Article 8
### Amendment

This MOU may be amended at any time by mutual written consent of the Parties. The
amendment(s) shall enter into force in accordance with the procedure prescribed in the
first paragraph of Article 9 of this MoU.

### Article 9
### Enforcement and Termination

1. This MoU shall enter into force on the date of the receipt of the last written notification
through diplomatic channels by which the Parties notify each other of the completion of
their internal procedures required for its entry into force.
2. This MoU shall remain in force for a period of five (5) years. Thereafter it will be
automatically renewed for further similar period or periods unless one of the Parties
notifies the other in writing and through diplomatic channels, about its intention to
terminate it 6 months before its expiration date.
3. The provisions of this Agreement/MoU do not disturb the applicable laws of the
two countries or the rights or obligations of any of the two countries arising from treaties
and International conventions to which any of them is a party.
4. The termination of this MOU, shall not affect the validity or the duration of any
specific agreements, projects and activities made under this MoU.

3# Decree No. 83 of 2025
## Approving an Air Services Agreement between the Government of the State of
## Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of Zimbabwe

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And the Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 AH, corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
- And Decree-Law No. 108 of 1976, amended by Decree-Law No. 53 of 1979, concerning the exemption of Arab and foreign airline companies from taxes,
- And Decree No. 84 of 2024 regarding Ministerial Substitutions and Delegations, and its amending decrees,
- And based on the proposal of the Minister of Foreign Affairs,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers,
We have decreed the following:

### Article One
Approval of the Agreement between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of Zimbabwe in the field of Air Services, signed in the city of Kuala Lumpur – Malaysia on 21 October 2024, the texts of which are attached to this Decree.

Each Contracting Party grants the other Contracting Party the rights specified in this Agreement for the purpose of operating international air services on the routes specified in the Route Schedule.
2. Subject to the provisions of this Agreement, the designated air transport enterprise(s) of each Contracting Party shall be granted the following rights:
    a. The right to fly across the territory of the other Contracting Party without landing.
    b. The right to make stops in the territory of the other Contracting Party for non-commercial purposes.
    c. The right to make stops at points on the routes specified in the Route Schedule agreed upon in this Agreement for the purpose of taking on and putting down international air traffic of passengers, cargo, and mail, or
    d. Other rights specified in this Agreement.
3. Air transport enterprises of both Contracting Parties – other than those designated pursuant to Article (4) (Designation and Authorization) of this Agreement – shall be entitled to enjoy the rights set forth in paragraphs (2)(a) and (2)(b) of this Article.
4. Nothing in this Article shall prevent the designated air transport enterprise(s) of one Contracting Party from exercising the privilege that allows it to operate on board an aircraft in the territory of the other Contracting Party, carrying passengers, goods, and mail for remuneration to another point in the territory of the other Contracting Party.

# Article 4
## Insurance and Indemnity

1. Each Contracting Party shall have the right to request in writing from the other Contracting Party one or more air transport enterprises for the purpose of operating the agreed services on the specified routes, and for this purpose, such designation shall be notified.
2. Upon receipt of such designation, the designated air transport enterprise shall request the map and procedures for operating authorization and the technical license, and each Contracting Party shall grant the appropriate authorization for operation with the least possible delay in procedures, in order to comply with the rights set forth in Article (3) of this Agreement, provided that the following are met:
    a. That the principal place of business of the air transport enterprise is in the territory of the Contracting Party designating that enterprise, and
    b. That the regulatory and financial control over the air transport enterprise is under the authority of that Contracting Party, and that the enterprise holds a valid Air Operator Certificate (AOC) issued by the Contracting Party designating it, and

Neither Contracting Party shall impose or permit to be imposed user charges on the designated air transport enterprises of the other Contracting Party higher than those imposed on its own air transport enterprises operating similar international services.
2. Each Contracting Party shall ensure that user charges for the use of air navigation services and airport facilities provided by the competent charging authorities, airport service providers, or air navigation service providers, and the air transport enterprises using such services and facilities, are established on a practical and non-discriminatory basis. Notice of any proposals for new user charges or changes to existing user charges shall be given in a reasonable period to the users of these services to enable them to express their views before the changes are implemented. Each Contracting Party shall also ensure that the charging authorities or service providers exchange information with the users regarding the user charges.

### Article 7
## Exemption from Customs Duties and Other Charges

1. Aircraft operated in international services by the designated air transport enterprise(s) of one Contracting Party, as well as their usual equipment, spare parts, passenger components, lubricating oils, and aircraft components (including food, beverages, and liquids on board), shall be exempt from all customs duties, inspection fees, and any other taxes or charges upon their arrival in the territory of the other Contracting Party, provided that such equipment remains in the State until the aircraft is sold there.
2. Ground equipment, lubricating oil containers, spare parts, consumable equipment, and aircraft components introduced into the territory of one Contracting Party by any designated air transport enterprise(s) of the other Contracting Party, or introduced on behalf of such enterprise(s) for the purpose of use in their international air service activities, shall be exempt from all national duties and taxes, including customs duties and inspection fees, imposed in the territory of the other Contracting Party, even if such equipment is to be used for part of its flights over the territory of the Contracting Party where the aircraft lands with this equipment. The aforementioned items may be required to remain under the supervision or control of the customs authorities.
3. Operating aircraft equipment, spare parts, and aircraft components, as well as quantities of fuel and lubricating oils on board an aircraft of either Contracting Party, shall be introduced into the territory of the other Contracting Party after approval by the authorities

(4) Movable property belonging to the designated air transport enterprise(s) of one Contracting Party, such as office equipment, vehicles, food, travel fuel including travel provisions, registration fees, and professional ranks, which are introduced into the territory of the other Contracting Party, shall be exempt from customs duties, insurance fees, and any other fees or taxes.
(5) In the event that a designated air transport enterprise(s) of one Contracting Party enters into arrangements with another air transport enterprise(s) for the purpose of utilizing or using any of the items specified in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) of this Article, the assistance mentioned in this Article shall be available to the enterprise undertaking such arrangements.

# Article 8
## Financial Provisions
Subject to the British regulations and documents that may apply, each Contracting Party undertakes to grant the designated air transport enterprise(s) of the other Contracting Party the right to freely transfer the excess of revenues over expenditures, based on the prevailing exchange rate (excluding any income earned on revenues and taxes on their transfer), from the proceeds of the carriage of passengers, baggage, mail, and cargo by the designated air transport enterprise(s) of the other Contracting Party. In the event that a special agreement exists, an agreement may be concluded between the two Contracting Parties, and that agreement shall apply.

# Article 9
## Facilitation of Air Transport and Services
(1) The designated air transport enterprise(s) of one Contracting Party shall have the right to be represented in the territory of the other Contracting Party.
(2) In accordance with the laws and regulations concerning entry, residence, and taxation in both Contracting Parties, the designated air transport enterprise(s) of one Contracting Party shall have the right to employ and utilize in the territory of the other Contracting Party administrative staff, sales staff, technicians, operations staff, and other specialized personnel necessary for the provision of air services.

(2) Each Contracting Party agrees to take the necessary measures to eliminate all forms of discrimination or unfair competitive practices that negatively affect the competitive position of an airline designated by the other Contracting Party.
(3) Air transport facilities granted for passenger traffic must be related to the general requirements for such transport.
(4) Each Contracting Party shall take into consideration the interests of the designated airlines of the other Contracting Party so as not to prejudice any reform imposed by the air traffic regulator mentioned in this Agreement.
(5) The primary consideration for the provision of agreed services by the designated airline under this Agreement shall be the establishment of reasonable capacity for exchanges between the two countries, where the airline acts as the sole ultimate means of transport. The airline in any Contracting Party's country, whether operating internationally or at a point within the territory of the other Contracting Party, must ensure that this does not prejudice or diminish the capacity of the airline in the country of the Agreement. This shall be in accordance with the provisions of the Article concerning the development of air traffic regulation undertaken by both Parties and shall be subject to capacity, provided that such capacity is integrated with:
a. The air traffic needs between the country of origin and the countries of final destination for air traffic;
b. The needs of transit operations carried out by the airline; and
c. The air traffic needs in the region through which the air route passes, after considering internal routes and necessary planning.
(6) Arrangements shall be made for consultations between the Parties whenever either Party requests a review of air capacity under this Agreement to ensure the adjustment of increased capacity in this Agreement to facilitate air planning.
(7) Each Contracting Party shall ensure that the designated airline's capacity and number of flights for international air transport traffic are provided in accordance with commercial market needs. In consistency with this, neither Contracting Party shall, when operating individually for transport entities according to the other's determination, do so except in accordance with the terms of this Agreement or as may be required by customs, or for security, operational, or environmental reasons, in accordance with the conditions mentioned in Article (15) of the Treaty.

  Designated air transport enterprises shall submit to the competent aviation authorities of both Contracting Parties, at least sixty (60) days prior to the commencement of the services to be applied on the specified routes in accordance with Article (3) of this Agreement, specifying the nature of the service, the types of aircraft used, the flight schedule, and any subsequent amendments.
2.  The aviation authorities receiving these operating schedules shall approve and endorse them or propose amendments thereto. In all cases, the designated air transport enterprises shall not commence their services before the schedules are approved by the concerned aviation authorities, and this also applies to subsequent amendments.

## Article 13
**Data and Statistics**
The aviation authorities of each Contracting Party shall provide the aviation authorities of the other Contracting Party, upon request, with periodic statistics or other statistical data that may be reasonably required.

## Article 14
**Determination of Tariffs**
1.  Both Contracting Parties shall permit the designated air transport enterprise to establish tariffs for air services based on commercial market principles, including operating costs, service characteristics, consumer interests, reasonable profit, and any other market considerations.
2.  Both Contracting Parties may request notification or registration of tariffs imposed for flights to and from their territory with their respective aviation authorities by the air transport enterprises designated by the other Contracting Party. Clarification of such notification or registration may be requested before the commencement of tariff setting by the air transport enterprises designated by both Contracting Parties.
3.  Without prejudice to the consumer protection laws in force and effect in each of the Contracting Parties, neither Contracting Party shall act in any way that prevents the commencement or continuation of a proposed or imposed tariff by a designated air transport enterprise of the other Contracting Party related to the air services stipulated in this Agreement, with minimal intervention as described in paragraph (4) below, consistent with:
    a. Preventing any unreasonable prices or pricing information.

c- the operation of air transport enterprises from artificially low prices.
(4) For the purposes of the provisions of paragraph (3) of this Article, the aeronautical authorities <orig>سلطات الطيران</orig> of both Contracting Parties <orig>الطرفين المتعاقدين</orig> may reject the tariff proposed by air transport enterprises <orig>مؤسسات النقل الجوي</orig> of the other Contracting Party if the aeronautical authorities discover that the tariff proposed by the transport enterprises falls within the scope of paragraph (3) of this Article. In this case, the concerned aeronautical authority shall:
a- send a notice of dissatisfaction to the aeronautical authorities of the other Contracting Party and the concerned air transport enterprise as soon as possible, and within a period of not less than thirty (30) days from the date of sending the notice or its provision to the Party.
b- request consultations in accordance with the procedures outlined in paragraph (3) of this Article. Unless both aeronautical authorities agree on the proposed tariff in writing, this tariff shall be deemed approved.
(5) The aeronautical authorities of either Contracting Party may request consultations with the aeronautical authorities of the other Contracting Party regarding any tariff proposed by an air transport enterprise of the other Contracting Party for international air transport services to or from the territory of the first Contracting Party, including tariffs for which a notice of disapproval has been submitted. These consultations shall be held within a period not exceeding fifteen (15) days from the date of receipt of the request. The aeronautical authorities of both Contracting Parties shall cooperate in providing the necessary information to reach an acceptable solution to the matter in dispute. Upon reaching an agreement on the tariff for which a notice of disapproval was sent, the aeronautical authorities of both Parties shall jointly confirm the disputed agreement. And in the event that a mutual agreement is not reached in this regard, then the tariff shall be deemed insufficient or shall continue to be applied.

(6) If a Contracting Party wishes to suspend or amend an operating authorization granted to an air transport enterprise of the other Contracting Party, other than what is concluded that such immediate action is necessary to ensure the safety of the air transport enterprise's operations, based on what may appear to be a suspicion of safety operation or a series of safety operations, or a refusal to permit such inspection, or what may appear from any consultations being conducted.
(7) Any action taken by one of the Contracting Parties under paragraphs (2) and (6) shall be suspended if the basis for taking such action so requires.
(8) Certificates of airworthiness – and certificates of competency and licenses issued or validated by one Contracting Party, and remaining in force, shall be recognized as valid by the other Contracting Party for the purpose of operating the air services permitted by this Agreement, provided that the requirements under which such certificates and licenses were issued or validated are equal to or higher than the minimum standards established or to be established pursuant to the Convention. (9) If the aeronautical authorities of a Contracting Party issue an authorization to a specific person or air transport enterprise(s) concerning the financing and training referred to in paragraph (8) of this Article, in relation to a phenomenon where the operator of the agreed services operates on the specified routes, and these rights or conditions are registered with the International Civil Aviation Organization <orig>منظمة الطيران المدني الدولي</orig> but are permitted by agreement of international standards under the Convention, then the aeronautical authorities of the other Contracting Party may request consultations with the aeronautical authorities of the first Contracting Party, in accordance with the provisions of Article (17) of this Agreement, with the aim of reaching an agreement that those rights and conditions are in force. After agreeing to reach a satisfactory agreement, this shall form the basis for the application of the provisions of Article (5) of this Agreement.

This must coincide with the dispatch of a copy of this notification to the Secretary-General of the International Civil Aviation Organization <orig>منظمة الطيران المدني الدولي</orig>. Upon such notification, this Agreement shall terminate after the expiration of twelve (12) months from the date of receipt of this notification by the other Contracting Party, unless it is withdrawn by agreement between the two Contracting Parties before the expiry of this period.
In the event that the other Contracting Party does not acknowledge receipt of the notification, it shall be deemed to have been notified after fourteen (14) days from the date the Secretary-General of the International Civil Aviation Organization <orig>منظمة الطيران المدني الدولي</orig> receives a copy of the notification.

## Article 20
### Conformity with Multilateral Treaties

Should a multilateral treaty specifically concerning air transport, to which both Contracting Parties are signatories, enter into force, this Agreement shall be amended to conform with the provisions of the multilateral treaty. Initiatives aimed at determining the extent to which this Agreement is to be terminated, amended, or modified or supplemented in accordance with the provisions of the multilateral treaty shall be in accordance with paragraph (2) of Article (17) of this Agreement.

## Article 21
### Registration

This Agreement and any amendment thereto shall be registered with the International Civil Aviation Organization <orig>منظمة الطيران المدني الدولي</orig>.

## Article 22
### Headings

The use of headings at the beginning of each Article in this Agreement is for ease of reference only and shall in no way define, limit, or describe the scope or content of this Agreement.

a) "Aeronautical Authorities" means in the case of the State of Kuwait, the Directorate General of Civil Aviation, and in the case of Zimbabwe, the Ministry responsible for aviation, or in both cases any other person or agency authorised to perform the functions exercised at present by the said authorities;

b) "Agreed Services" means scheduled air services on the routes specified in the Annex to this Agreement for the transport of passengers, cargo and mail in accordance with the agreed capacity entitlements;

c) "Agreement" means this Agreement, its Annex, and any amendments thereto;

d) "Air Service", "International Air Service", "Stop for Non-Traffic Purposes" and "Airline" shall for the purpose of this Agreement, have the meaning laid down in Article (96) of the Convention;

e) "Air Transportation" means the public carriage by aircraft of passengers, baggage, cargo and mail, separately or in combination, for remuneration or hire;

f) "Convention" means the Convention on International Civil Aviation opened for signature at Chicago on the seventh day of December 1944, and includes any annex adopted under Article (90) of that Convention and any amendment of the Annexes or Convention under Articles (90) and (94) thereof so far as these Annexes and amendments have been adopted by both Contracting Parties;

g) "Designated Airline" means any airline that one Contracting Party has designated in writing to the other Contracting Party in accordance with Article (4) of this Agreement as being an airline which is to operate the agreed services on the routes specified in accordance with Article (3) of this Agreement;

h) "Route Schedule" means the Route Schedule annexed to this Agreement or as amended in accordance with the provisions of Article (17) of this Agreement;

i) "Tariff" means the prices to be paid for the carriage of passengers, baggage and cargo and the conditions under which those prices apply, including prices and conditions for agency and other auxiliary services, but excluding remuneration and conditions for the carriage of mail;

j) "Territory" in relation to a State, has the meaning assigned to it in Article (2) of the Convention;

<header>
Kuwait Today / Al-Kuwait Al-Youm <orig>الكويت اليوم</orig> Issue No. 1738, Seventy-First Year
187 Sunday, 13 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1446 AH, 11/5/2025 AD
</header>
# ARTICLE 7

## EXEMPTIONS FROM CUSTOM DUTIES AND OTHER CHARGES

1.  Aircrafts operated on international air services by the designated airline(s) of one Contracting Party, as well as their regular equipment, spare parts, supplies of fuels and lubricants and aircraft stores (including food, beverages and tobacco) on board such aircraft shall be exempt from all customs duties, inspection fees and other duties or taxes on arriving in the territory of the other Contracting Party, provided such equipment and supplies remain on board the aircraft up to such time as they are re-exported.
2.  Supplies of fuels, lubricants, spare parts, regular equipment and aircraft stores introduced in the territory of each Contracting Party or on behalf of the designated airline(s) of the other Contracting Party or taken on board the aircraft operated by such designated airline(s) and intended solely for use in the operation of international air services shall be exempt from all national duties and charges, including customs duties and inspection fees imposed in the territory of the first Contracting Party, even when those supplies are to be used on the parts of the journey performed over the territory of the Contracting Party in which they are taken on board. The materials referred to above may be required to be kept under customs supervision or control.
3.  The regular airborne equipment, spare parts, aircraft stores and supplies of fuels and lubricants retained on board the aircraft of either Contracting Party may be unloaded in the territory of the other Contracting Party only with the approval of the customs authorities of that Contracting Party, who may require that those materials be placed under their supervision up to such time as they are re-exported or otherwise disposed of in accordance with customs regulations.
4.  Moveable properties of the designated airline(s) of one Contracting Party such as office equipment, stationery, travel documents including airline tickets, airway bills as well as publicity material and give-away items, introduced in the territory of the other Contracting Party shall be exempt from all customs duties, inspection fees and other duties or taxes.
5.  In the event that the designated airline or airlines of one Contracting Party owing to an emergency situation enter into arrangement with another airline or airlines for the loan or use of any of the items specified in paragraphs (1), (2) and (3) of this Article, the relieves provided in this article shall be available to such airline.

## FINANCIAL PROVISIONS

Subject to the national laws and regulations of each Contracting Party, each
Contracting Party undertakes to grant the designated airline or airlines of the other
Contracting Party the right of free transfer, at the applicable rate of exchange, of the
excess of receipts over expenditure (including any interest earned on deposit awaiting
remittance) achieved in its territory in connection with the carriage of passengers,
baggage, mail shipments and cargo by the designated airline or airlines of the other
Contracting Party.

3) The air transport facilities available to the travelling public should bear a close relationship to the requirements of the public for such transport.
4) Each Contracting Party shall take into consideration the interests of the designated airlines of the other Contracting Party so as not to affect unduly their opportunity to offer the services covered by this Agreement.
5) Services provided by a designated airline under the Agreement shall retain as their primary objective the provision of capacity adequate to the traffic demands between the countries of which such airline is a national and the country of ultimate destination of the traffic. The right to embark or disembark on such services international traffic destined for and coming from third countries at a point or points on the routes specified in this Agreement shall be exercised in accordance with the general principles of orderly development of international air transport to which both Contracting Parties subscribe and shall be subject to the general principle that capacity should be related to:
    a. The traffic requirements between the country of origin and the countries of ultimate destination of the traffic;
    b. The requirements of through airline operations; and
    c. The traffic requirements of the area through which the airline passes, after taking account of local and regional services.
6) Consultations between the Contracting Parties shall be arranged whenever a Contracting Party requests that the capacity provided under the Agreement be reviewed to ensure the application of the principles in the Agreement governing the conduct of the services.

# ARTICLE 14
## ESTABLISHMENT OF TARIFFS

1.  Each Contracting Party shall allow tariffs for air services to be established by each designated airline based on commercial considerations in the market place, including the cost of operation, the characteristics of the service, the interests of users, a reasonable profit and other market considerations.
2.  Each Contracting Party may require notification to or filing with its aeronautical authorities of tariffs to be charged to or from its territory by airlines of the other Contracting Party. Such notification or filing by the airlines of both Contracting Parties may be required to be made no later than the initial offering of a price.
3.  Without prejudice to the applicable competition and consumer protection laws prevailing in each Contracting Party, neither Contracting Party shall take unilateral action to prevent the commencement or continuation of a tariff proposed to be charged or charged by a designated airline of the other Contracting Party in connection with the international air services provided for under this Agreement. Intervention, as described in paragraph (4) below, by the Contracting Parties shall be limited to:
    a. Prevention of unreasonably discriminatory prices or practices;
    b. Protection of consumers from prices that are unreasonably high or restrictive due to the abuse of a dominant position or due to concerted practice among airlines;
    c. Protection of airlines from prices that are artificially low.
4.  Without prejudice to the provisions of paragraph (3) of this Article, the aeronautical authorities of either Contracting Party may expressly disapprove tariffs submitted by the designated airlines of the other Contracting Party, where such aeronautical authorities find that a tariff proposed to be charged by such airlines falls within the categories set forth in paragraph (3) of this Article. In such event, the concerned aeronautical authority:
    a. Shall send notification of its dissatisfaction to the aeronautical authorities of the other Contracting Party, and to the airline involved, as soon as possible, and in no event later than thirty (30) days after the date of notification or filing of the tariff in question; and
    b. May request consultations in accordance with the procedures established under paragraph (3) of this Article. Unless both aeronautical authorities

5) The aeronautical authorities of each Contracting Party may request consultations
with the aeronautical authorities of the other Contracting Party on any tariff charged
by an airline of the other Contracting Party for international air services to or from

for which a notice of dissatisfaction has been given, the aeronautical authorities of

Each Contracting Party agrees that its designated
airline or airlines may be required to observe the aviation security provisions
referred to in paragraph (3) required by the other Contracting Party for entrance
into, departure from, or while within, the territory of that other Contracting Party.
Each Contracting Party shall also act favourably upon any request from the other
Contracting Party for reasonable special security measures to meet a particular
threat.

5) When an incident or threat of an incident of unlawful seizure of civil aircraft or
other unlawful acts against the safety of such aircraft, their passengers and crew,
airports or air navigation facilities occurs, the Contracting Parties shall assist each
other by facilitating communications and other appropriate measures intended to
terminate as rapidly as possible commensurate with minimum risk to life such
incident or threat.

6) Each Contracting Party shall take such measures, as it may find practicable, to
ensure that an aircraft subject to an act of unlawful seizure or other acts of unlawful
interference which has landed in its territory is detained on the ground unless its
departure is necessitated by the overriding duty to protect human life. Wherever
practicable, such measures shall be taken on the basis of mutual consultations.

7) When a Contracting Party has reasonable grounds to believe that the other
Contracting Party has departed from the provisions of this Article, the first
Contracting Party may request immediate consultations. Such consultations shall
start within fifteen (15) days of receipt of such a request from either Contracting
Party. Failure to reach a satisfactory agreement within fifteen (15) days from the
start of consultations, or such other period as may be agreed upon between the
Contracting Parties, shall constitute grounds for withholding, revoking, suspending
or imposing conditions on the authorisations of the airline or airlines designated by
the other Contracting Party. When justified by an emergency, or to prevent further
non-compliance with the provisions of this Article, the first Contracting Party may
take interim action at any time. Any action taken in accordance with this paragraph
shall be discontinued upon compliance by the other Contracting Party with the
security provisions of this Article.

2) If the Contracting Parties fail to reach within sixty (60) days a settlement by negotiations they shall refer the dispute for decision to a person or body or at the request of one of the Contracting Parties to an arbitration tribunal. The arbitration tribunal shall be composed as follows:
    a. Each Contracting Party shall nominate an arbitrator, if one Contracting Party fails to nominate its arbitrator within sixty (60) days, such arbitrator shall be nominated by the President of the Council of the International Civil Aviation Organization at the request of the other Contracting Party.
    b. The third arbitrator, who shall be a national of a third state and who shall preside over the arbitration tribunal, shall be nominated either:
        i. By agreement between the Contracting Parties; or
        ii. If within sixty (60) days the Contracting Parties do not so agree, by appointment of the President of the Council of the International Civil Aviation Organization by the request of either Contracting Party. If the President of the Council is of the same nationality as one of the Contracting Parties, the most senior Vice President who is not disqualified on that ground shall make the appointment.

3) The arbitral tribunal shall reach its decisions by a majority of votes. Such decisions shall be binding on both Contracting Parties. Each Contracting Party shall bear the cost of its own member as well as of its representation in the arbitral proceedings; the cost of the chairman and any other costs shall be borne in equal parts by the Contracting Parties. In all other respects, the arbitral tribunal shall have its own procedure.

4) The arbitral tribunal shall attempt to give a written decision within sixty (60) days after completion of the hearing or, if no hearing is held, sixty (60) days after the date both replies are submitted.

5) The decision of the arbitral tribunal shall be final and binding upon the parties to the dispute.

## TERMINATION

# Decree No. 84 of 2025
## Approving a Memorandum of Understanding between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the State of Qatar in the Field of Charitable and Humanitarian Work

– Having reviewed the Constitution,
– And the Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 AH, corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
– And Decree No. 84 of 2024 regarding Ministerial Substitutions and Delegations, and its amending decrees,
– And based on the proposal of the Minister of Foreign Affairs,
– And after the approval of the Council of Ministers,

We have decreed the following:

### Article One
Approval of the Memorandum of Understanding between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the State of Qatar in the field of charitable and humanitarian work, signed in the city of Doha <orig>الدوحة</orig> on 4/9/2024, the texts of which are attached to this Decree.

### Article Two
Ministers – each within their respective jurisdiction – shall implement this Decree, which shall come into force from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette.

Amir of Kuwait
Mishal Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah <orig>مشعل الأحمد الجابر الصباح</orig>

Acting Prime Minister
Fahad Yusuf Saud Al-Sabah <orig>فهد يوسف سعود الصباح</orig>

Minister of Foreign Affairs
Abdullah Ali Abdullah Al-Yahya <orig>عبدالله علي عبدالله اليحيا</orig>

<footer>
