# Memorandum of Understanding between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the State of Qatar in the Field of Charitable and Humanitarian Work

The Government of the State of Kuwait, represented by the Ministry of Social Affairs <orig>وزارة الشؤون الاجتماعية</orig>, and the Government of the State of Qatar, represented by the Regulatory Authority for Charitable Activities <orig>هيئة تنظيم الأعمال الخيرية</orig>, hereinafter referred to as "the Two Parties",
Desiring to strengthen and consolidate the bonds of brotherhood between them and to enhance cooperation in developing, supporting, encouraging, regulating, and supervising charitable and humanitarian work in both countries;

**The Two Parties have agreed as follows:**

## Article (1)

The Two Parties shall work to establish the necessary rules, applications, and regulations for implementing the provisions of this Memorandum, in accordance with the national legislations in both countries and the international agreements to which both States are parties.

# Memorandum of Understanding between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the State of Qatar in the Field of Charitable and Humanitarian Work

The Government of the State of Kuwait, represented by the Ministry of Social Affairs <orig>وزارة الشؤون الاجتماعية</orig>, and the Government of the State of Qatar, represented by the Regulatory Authority for Charitable Activities <orig>هيئة تنظيم الأعمال الخيرية</orig>, hereinafter referred to as "the Two Parties,"
Desiring to strengthen and consolidate the bonds of brotherhood between them and to enhance cooperation in developing, supporting, encouraging, regulating, and supervising charitable and humanitarian work in both countries;

**The Two Parties have agreed as follows:**

## Article (1)

The Two Parties shall work to establish the necessary rules, applications, and regulations for implementing the provisions of this Memorandum, in accordance with the national legislations in both countries and the international agreements to which both states are parties.

## Article (2)

This Memorandum shall not prejudice any rights or obligations of either Party arising from any international agreements or other treaties to which either Party is a member or a party, nor shall it conflict with any national legislations.

### Article (3)
To achieve the objectives of this Memorandum and to ensure the activation of the agreed-upon areas of cooperation, the two Parties shall work on the following:
1. Exchange of expertise and experiences in the field of implementing and reporting on internal technical work in affairs.
2. Exchange of expertise and experiences related to scientific studies and research in the field of developing technical and administrative work.
3. Exchange of knowledge in the field of capacity building for public bodies, and the cadres of private charitable associations and institutions, and relevant partners.
4. Cooperation in the field of mutual training and linking workshops, conferences, and seminars.
5. Exchange of expertise in the field of best practices concerning legislation and specific applications for charitable and humanitarian work, with the aim of guidance.
6. Cooperation between them through the exchange of expertise in the field of supervision and oversight of non-profit organizations, charitable institutions, private charitable associations, and non-profit organizations to contribute to the development of charitable and humanitarian projects.
7. Exchange of expertise in the field of enhancing transparency, integrity, and public accuracy in the management of non-profit organizations.

### Article (4)
Based on the provisions of this Memorandum, the two Parties agree to form a joint committee comprising (3) three members from each Party, entrusted with the following tasks:
1. Coordination between the two Parties in implementing this Memorandum and taking necessary measures in this regard.
2. Preparation of the necessary executive activities and procedures for the implementation of this Memorandum.
3. Preparation of the annual cooperation plan for the agreed-upon cooperation facilities.
4. Determination of practical mechanisms and opinions for implementing the agreed-upon cooperation plan.

6. Proposing the review or amendment of all or some articles of this Memorandum when necessary.
7. The Joint Committee shall meet whenever necessary, at a time and place to be agreed upon by both parties.

### Article (5)

Each party shall work to inform the representative <orig>الممثلة</orig> of the participation of Wafatt <orig>وفت</orig> in these activities and meetings of the Joint Committee.

### Article (6)

Both parties undertake to maintain the confidentiality of the other party's information, and not to disclose it directly or indirectly, or reveal it in any manner whatsoever to any third party without the prior explicit written consent of the other party, except within the limits permitted by the laws and regulations in force in both parties and governing the work of both parties.

### Article (7)

This Memorandum is considered an expression of the good intentions of both parties to cooperate in developing, supporting, encouraging, and promoting Arab and Islamic works, and supervising and sponsoring them in the countries, and does not create any other rights or obligations for either party.

### Article (8)

Any dispute or disagreement that may arise between the Parties regarding the interpretation or application of this Memorandum or any of its provisions shall be settled amicably between the Parties through consultation and negotiation, via diplomatic channels.

### Article (9)

This Memorandum or any of its provisions may be amended by written agreement between the Parties. Such amendments shall enter into force in accordance with the same procedures stipulated in Article (10) of this Memorandum.

### Article (10)

This Memorandum shall enter into force from the date of receipt by either Party of the last written notification from the other Party, through diplomatic channels, confirming the completion of its necessary internal legal procedures for the entry into force of this Memorandum, as stipulated in both countries. This Memorandum shall remain valid for a period of (3) three years and shall be automatically renewed for one or more similar periods, unless one Party notifies the other Party in writing, through diplomatic channels, of its desire to terminate it, at least (3) three months prior to its termination date or the expiry of its original term.

The termination of this Memorandum or the expiry of its term shall not affect ongoing programs and activities, which shall continue until their completion, unless the Parties agree otherwise in writing.

In witness thereof, the undersigned plenipotentiaries, duly authorized by their respective Governments, have signed this Memorandum.

# Decree No. 85 of 2025 <orig>مرسوم رقم 85 لسنة 2025</orig>
Approving a Memorandum of Understanding <orig>مذكرة تفاهم</orig> for Cooperation in the Field of Social Affairs <orig>الشؤون الاجتماعية</orig> between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Government of the State of Qatar <orig>دولة قطر</orig>

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And on the Amiri Order <orig>الأمر الأميري</orig> issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 AH, corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
- And on Decree <orig>المرسوم</orig> No. 84 of 2024 regarding Ministerial Substitutions and Delegations <orig>الحلول والإنابات الوزارية</orig>, and its amending decrees,
- And based on the proposal of the Minister of Foreign Affairs <orig>وزير الخارجية</orig>,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>,

We have decreed the following:

## Article One <orig>مادة أولى</orig>
Approval of the Memorandum of Understanding <orig>مذكرة تفاهم</orig> for Cooperation in the Field of Social Affairs <orig>الشؤون الاجتماعية</orig> between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Government of the State of Qatar <orig>دولة قطر</orig>, signed in the city of Doha <orig>الدوحة</orig> on 4/9/2024, the texts of which are attached to this Decree <orig>مرسوم</orig>.

# Memorandum of Understanding for Cooperation
## In the Field of Social Affairs Between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the State of Qatar

The Government of the State of Kuwait, represented by the "Ministry of Social Affairs <orig>وزارة الشؤون الاجتماعية</orig>", and the Government of the State of Qatar, represented by the "Ministry of Social Development and Family <orig>وزارة التنمية الاجتماعية والأسرة</orig>", hereinafter referred to as the Parties.

Desiring to strengthen and consolidate the long-standing fraternal ties between them, and to embody the common objectives of the Parties in the field of social affairs.

Have agreed as follows:

### Article (1)

The Parties shall work to exchange expertise, information, studies, and projects, and organize joint programs for rehabilitation, training, and encouraging innovation in the following areas of social affairs:

1.  Social Security <orig>الضمان الاجتماعي</orig>
2.  Affairs of Productive Families
3.  Projects related to combating begging and providing assistance
4.  Family monitoring in the field of social affairs directed at the following categories:
    a. Affairs of the elderly and persons with disabilities.
    b. Juvenile delinquents, and children of unknown parentage.
    c. Women and child affairs.
5.  Initial consultation and projects that contribute to strengthening the role of civil society institutions.
6.  Supporting cooperation between civil society institutions working in the field of social affairs.
7.  Activating the resolutions of the Supreme Council of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> related to social affairs.
8.  Activating<image_caption>State of Qatar Official Seal</image_caption>


### Article (2)
The Parties shall work to enhance and develop means of joint cooperation in the fields of social affairs in both countries and prepare an annual plan that includes programs and activities ensuring the activation of this cooperation.

### Article (2)
The two Parties shall work to enhance and qualify means of joint cooperation in social affairs in both countries and prepare an annual plan that includes programs and activities to ensure the activation of this cooperation.

### Article (3)
Each Party shall provide the other Party with the opportunity to review its experiences and expertise in the field of social affairs and to seek ways to benefit from them.

### Article (4)
To achieve the objectives of this Memorandum and to ensure the activation of the areas of cooperation referred to in Article (1) thereof, the two Parties shall do the following:
1. Exchange delegation visits between the two countries to review their experiences in the field of social affairs.
2. Exchange experts to implement the aforementioned programs.
3. Exchange information, scientific publications, and electronic recommendations.
4. Organize seminars, conferences, and joint activities related to social affairs between specialists in both countries.

### Article (5)
A joint working team consisting of (3) three members from each country shall be formed to carry out the following tasks:
1. Ensure the seriousness of the Memorandum.
2. Prepare regulations and develop future projects to ensure the implementation of the Memorandum.
3. Report on the completion of this Memorandum and study whether there are any drafts upon completion and issuance, or review or amend some clauses if required.

### Article (6)
1.  The sending Party shall bear the travel expenses of its delegation, including living expenses, for round trips. The host Party shall bear the expenses for accommodation, transportation, and emergency medical treatment for the delegations of the other Party, in accordance with the arrangements agreed upon in this regard.
2.  The sending Party shall bear all [expenses] during training missions.
3.  The host Party shall bear the cost of information transfer, information exchange, and training tools.

### Article (7)
This Memorandum shall not affect the obligations arising from bilateral, regional, and international agreements to which either Party is a signatory.

### Article (8)
The Parties shall implement this Memorandum in accordance with the laws and regulations in force in both countries.

### Article (9)
Any dispute arising from the interpretation and application of this Memorandum shall be settled amicably by both Parties through diplomatic channels.

### Article (10)
1.  This Memorandum of Understanding shall enter into force from the date of the last written notification by which either Party informs the other, in writing and through diplomatic channels, of the completion of all necessary national legal procedures for its entry into force.
This Memorandum shall remain in force for a period of five years and shall be automatically renewed unless one Party notifies the other in writing of its desire to terminate it six months prior to its expiry date.

# Memorandum of Understanding between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Sultanate of Oman on Cooperation in the Land Transport Sector

The Government of the State of Kuwait, represented by the "Public Authority for Roads and Land Transport <orig>الهيئة العامة للطرق والنقل البري</orig>", and the Government of the Sultanate of Oman, represented by the "Ministry of Transport, Communications and Information Technology <orig>وزارة النقل والاتصالات وتقنية المعلومات</orig>" (hereinafter referred to as "the Parties").

Desiring to enhance the existing cooperation between the two countries on the basis of equality, reciprocity, and mutual benefit for the interest of both countries, and to work towards expanding cooperation in the field of land transport.

And recognizing the readiness of both Parties to share knowledge and expertise, including technical knowledge in the field of land transport, for the benefit of present and future endeavors alike, thereby achieving sustainable development, and affirming that this cooperation will serve common interests and contribute to enhancing regional cooperation in the field of land transport, in addition to creating a suitable environment for trade and navigation by establishing that this cooperation will increase further economic and commercial exchange, and in accordance with the laws and regulations in force in both countries.

Have agreed as follows:

## Article (1)

The Parties shall develop programs related to the land transport sector in which they have a mutual interest, through the following:
1- Establishing the legal foundations for cooperation in the field of land transport between the two countries.
2- Exchanging knowledge and institutional cooperation, which includes capacity building and expertise.

State of Kuwait
Ali Al-Mousa <orig>علي الموسى</orig>
Deputy Director General for Asset Affairs

Sultanate of Oman
Ali bin Masoud Al-Sunaidy <orig>علي بن مسعود السنيدي</orig>
Minister of Transport and Communications

3- Expanding the scope of cooperation to develop competition between governmental institutions and companies in the land transport sector in both countries.

- 4- Encouraging efforts to establish and develop direct cooperation relations between public and private institutions.
- 5- Exchanging laws, provisions, and regulating rules applicable to both Parties in the field of land transport.
- 6- Exchanging visits of senior officials, experts, and consultants.
- 7- Organizing joint seminars, conferences, and seasonal events on topics of common interest and other specified administrative activities.

The two Parties may, by mutual agreement, discuss other areas of cooperation through diplomatic channels.

### Article (2)

The two Parties shall implement all provisions of this Memorandum, evaluate and follow up on the cooperation activities stipulated in Article (1) of this Memorandum, and establish implementation procedures for any agreed-upon cooperative activity. Either Party may determine the method of implementation within its affiliated institutions and companies.

### Article (3)

Each Party shall treat with utmost confidentiality all information and documents exchanged and services provided in implementation of the provisions of this Memorandum. Neither Party shall disclose such information or documents to a third party except after obtaining the prior written consent of the other Party. This obligation shall continue for a period of (3) three years from the date of expiration or termination of this Memorandum.

### Article (4)

This Memorandum shall be implemented in accordance with the laws and regulations in force in both countries, and in accordance with the principles of availability of funds and personnel from both Parties.

### Article (6)
The two Parties shall sign this Memorandum upon the approval of the government of each Party.

### Article (7)
Any disputes arising between the two Parties concerning the interpretation or implementation of the provisions of this Memorandum shall be settled amicably between the two Parties through consultations via diplomatic channels.

### Article (8)
This Memorandum may be amended by the two Parties by agreement through diplomatic channels, and such amendment shall enter into force in accordance with the same procedures stipulated in Paragraph 1 of Article 9.

### Article (9)
1. This Memorandum of Understanding shall enter into force from the date of receipt of the latter notification, in which one Party notifies the other Party, through diplomatic channels, of the completion of the necessary constitutional procedures for its entry into force.
2. This Memorandum of Understanding shall remain in force for a period of 3 years from the date of its entry into force and shall be automatically renewed for a similar period, unless one Party notifies the other Party in writing, through diplomatic channels, of its desire to terminate this Agreement six (6) months prior to its expiry date.

# Memorandum of Understanding
## In the Field of Social Affairs
### Between
## The Government of the State of Kuwait
### And
## The Government of the Republic of Tunisia

The Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of Tunisia
(hereinafter referred to as "the Parties"),
Desiring to strengthen and consolidate the bonds of Arab brotherhood between them, and wishing to cooperate in the field of social affairs, the Parties have agreed as follows:

## Article One
The Parties shall work to exchange expertise, information, studies, and legislation in the following areas:
1.  Family and Childhood Affairs.
2.  Small and Medium-sized Enterprises.
3.  Social Welfare (Special Categories).
4.  Cooperative Societies.
5.  Services for the Elderly and Children of Unknown Parentage.
6.  Women's Affairs.
7.  Youth Affairs.
8.  Supporting and developing the role of civil society institutions in activating the role of civil society institutions in the field of social development.
9.  Supporting and developing civil society institutions working in the field of social affairs, highlighting their activities, and facilitating effective participation in the field of social cooperation.
<page_end>224</page_end>

## Article Two
The two parties shall work to encourage and activate means of joint cooperation in social affairs
in both countries and adopt an annual plan for coordination on programs and activities that ensure the activation of this
cooperation.

## Article Three
Each party shall provide the other party with the opportunity to review its experiences and expertise in social
affairs and seek ways to benefit from them.

## Article Four
The competent authorities and their representatives shall receive requests for cooperation referred to in Article One.
The two parties shall undertake the following:
- Exchange visits of delegations between technical experts to review their experiences in social
affairs.
- Exchange experts to share joint programs between them and appoint representatives from both parties.
- Exchange information, technical publications, and electronic software.
- Organize joint courses, conferences, and activities related to social affairs between
specialists in both countries.

## Article Five
A joint working team consisting of three members from each country shall be formed to carry out the following tasks:
- Agree on joint tasks.
- Prepare activities and develop future programs necessary for the implementation of this Memorandum.
- Evaluate the provisions of this Memorandum and recommend any amendments deemed necessary during implementation, and propose
a review or amendment regarding the provisions of this Memorandum.
- Evaluate and follow up on the achievement of joint tasks and submit an annual report thereon to the Ministers of
Social Affairs <orig>وزيري الشؤون الاجتماعية</orig> in both countries.
- The joint working team shall meet once a year, alternately in both countries, and whenever
necessary.

## Article Six
The sending party shall bear the travel expenses of its delegates to the host party, round trip, and the
host party shall bear the expenses of accommodation, lodging, and medical treatment in accordance with the rules followed in both countries.
- The joint party shall bear the expenses of conferences and events.
- The organizing party shall bear all expenses for printing and publishing publications, papers, and brochures.

## Article Eight
The two Parties shall implement this Memorandum in accordance with the laws and regulations in force in both countries.

## Article Nine
Any dispute related to the implementation or interpretation of this Memorandum shall be settled amicably through consultation between the two Parties via diplomatic channels.

## Article Ten
- This Memorandum of Understanding shall enter into force from the date of receipt of the last notification by one Party to the other, confirming the completion of their essential internal procedures related to the national procedures necessary for its entry into force.
- This Memorandum of Understanding shall be valid for a period of two years from its date of entry into force and shall be automatically renewed for a similar period or periods, unless one Party notifies the other Party in writing, through diplomatic channels, of its desire to terminate this Memorandum at least six (6) months prior to the expiry of the initial period or any subsequent period.
- This Memorandum may be amended by agreement of the two Parties, at any time, by bringing such amendments into force in accordance with the procedures set forth in the first paragraph of this Article.
- The termination or expiry of this Memorandum shall not affect the validity of all ongoing activities that have commenced implementation, until their completion, unless the two Parties agree otherwise.

## Article Eleven
This Memorandum was concluded at the headquarters of the Cooperation in the Field of Labor and Social Affairs for the Conference in the city of Tunis on May 20, 2016.

## Facts

Whereas the facts – as evident from the referral judgment and all other documents – indicate that the plaintiff bank (Commercial Bank of Kuwait <orig>البنك التجاري الكويتي</orig>) filed lawsuit No. (18492) for the year 2021, Commercial Plenary /32, against the defendant company (Gulf Insurance Company <orig>شركة الخليج للتأمين</orig>), requesting a judgment obliging it to pay the amount of (K.D. 43,498.951) along with any accrued contractual interest at a rate of (3%) annually above the discount rate announced by the Central Bank <orig>البنك المركزي</orig> from the date of the notice of payment on 6/10/2019 until the full and final settlement of the debt. This was based on the assertion that, pursuant to a loan agreement dated 8/10/2018, Saeed Munif Saeed Al-Mutairi <orig>سعيد منيف سعيد المطيري</orig> obtained a personal loan of (K.D. 42,000) deposited into his account with the bank, to be repaid in (180) monthly installments of (K.D. 355) each. However, on 18/1/2019, the aforementioned client passed away after repaying part of the debt. Since the bank had insured the lives of its borrowers under a group insurance policy with the appellant company, and the insured risk materialized with the death of the borrowing client, leaving an outstanding amount of (K.D. 43,498.951) from the principal loan and accrued interest, the bank notified the company and instructed it to pay on 6/10/2019. However, the company refused to pay, leading the bank to file the present lawsuit with the aforementioned requests.
On 30/5/2023, the first instance court ruled to dismiss the lawsuit. The plaintiff bank appealed this judgment with appeal No. (4231) for the year 2023, Commercial /19. The defendant company submitted a memorandum in which it argued
President of the Court
Session Secretary
the unconstitutionality of the third paragraph of Article (791) of the Civil Code <orig>القانون المدني</orig> regarding its provision obliging the insurer to pay the insurance amount and depriving him of the right to request the annulment of the contract if the truth emerged after the risk materialized, without differentiating between the good-faith insured and the bad-faith insured, in violation of Articles (7) and (8) of the Constitution. On 9/1/2024, the Court of Appeal ruled to suspend the appeal proceedings and refer it to the Constitutional Court <orig>المحكمة الدستورية</orig> to decide on the constitutionality of the third paragraph of Article (791) of the Civil Code <orig>القانون المدني</orig>.
Following the arrival of the case file at the clerk's office of this Court, it was registered under No. (1) for the year 2024 "Constitutional," and the concerned parties were notified accordingly.
This Court heard the lawsuit in its session on 5/2/2025, as detailed in its minutes. The plaintiff, on behalf of the defendant, submitted a memorandum concluding with a request for a judgment of inadmissibility of the lawsuit, and alternatively, its rejection. The representative for the defendant submitted a memorandum concluding with a request for a judgment of unconstitutionality of the challenged text. The Department of Fatwa and Legislation <orig>إدارة الفتوى والتشريع</orig> submitted a memorandum on behalf of the government's defense, concluding with a request for a judgment of inadmissibility of the lawsuit, and alternatively, its rejection. The Court decided to issue its judgment in the session today.

## Reasoning

After reviewing the documents, hearing the pleadings, and deliberating.
Whereas the referral procedures have fulfilled their legally prescribed conditions.
Whereas Article (791) of the Civil Code <orig>القانون المدني</orig> stipulates that: "1- The insurance contract shall be voidable in favor of the insurer if the insured remained silent about a matter or provided an incorrect statement, and this was likely to change the subject of the risk or reduce its importance in the insurer's view. 2- If the truth was revealed before the risk materialized, the insurer may request the annulment of the contract after ten days from the date of notifying the insured by registered letter, unless the latter accepts an increase in the premium proportionate to the increase in the risk. The annulment of the contract in this case entails that the insurer returns the insurance consideration or returns the amount for which no risk was borne. 3- However, if the truth appeared after the risk materialized, the insurance amount must be reduced by the ratio of the premium rates actually paid to the premium rates that should have been paid if the risks had been correctly declared to the insurer."
Whereas the basis of the complaint against the third paragraph of the aforementioned Article – as evident from the referral judgment – is that it equated the good-faith insured and the bad-faith insured in the event of providing incorrect data and the truth appearing after the risk materialized, as both are compensated without differentiation according to the proportional rule, thereby depriving the insurer of his right to request the annulment of the contract, whereas the application of that rule should have been limited to the good-faith insured only, which violates Articles (7) and (8) of the Constitution.
Whereas this complaint is refutable, as it is established – and as the jurisprudence of this Court has held – that the discretionary power possessed by the legislator in accordance with
<page_end>227</page_end>

<page_start>228</page_start>
<page_metadata>
{
  "page_title": "Court Ruling on Insurance Contracts and Constitutional Review <orig>حكم المحكمة بشأن عقود التأمين والرقابة الدستورية</orig>",

  "publisher": "Kuwait Today / Al-Kuwait Al-Youm <orig>الكويت اليوم</orig>",
  "page_summary": "This page presents a court judgment rejecting a lawsuit, detailing the legal framework for insurance contracts under the Civil Code (Articles 773-809), the legislator's intent to protect the insured, and the scope of judicial review concerning the constitutionality of legislative texts."
}
</page_metadata>
<header>
228
Sunday, 13 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1446 AH – 2025/5/11
Kuwait Today / Al-Kuwait Al-Youm <orig>الكويت اليوم</orig> Issue 1738, Seventy-First Year
</header>
The legislator, in this regard, took into account that the insurer, as the stronger party in the insurance contract, has the right to include any conditions it wishes in the insurance contract to define the scope of the insured risk and the conditions of its coverage. The insured, on the other hand, has no choice but to accept these conditions, as long as they do not violate the law, in addition to the insurer's right to take all necessary measures to verify the accuracy of the data provided by the insured. If the contract is concluded according to the conditions set by the insurer, and after verifying the accuracy of the data submitted by the insured, and the contract continues until the risk materializes, and then the inaccuracy of some of this data becomes apparent, the legislator, in this case, deemed it appropriate to allow the contract to remain in force and its effects to be arranged, with a reduction in the insurance amount that the insurer is obligated to pay, in proportion to that. The matter was left to the judiciary to estimate this proportion in a way that achieves justice between the two parties, so that the legislative regulation envisioned by the legislator in this regard does not violate Articles (7) and (8) of the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig>.

It goes without saying in this context that the judicial oversight exercised by this Court, which the legislator has entrusted to it, does not extend to replacing a new ruling with the ruling contained in the challenged legislative text or supplementing its ruling with another ruling. Rather, its oversight is limited to taking the apparent meaning of the challenged text as a basis for examining its constitutionality, considering that the review of this Court is a constitutional review, not one of expediency. Furthermore, the presumption of constitutionality accompanying legislation assumes the conformity of legislative texts with the provisions of the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig>, and every possible presumption should be in favor of the legislation unless this presumption is rebutted by conclusive evidence that, in itself, definitively negates the constitutionality of the challenged text, which is not realized in the present constitutional case.

Consequently, based on the foregoing, it is necessary to rule to dismiss the case.

For these reasons,
The Court ruled: to dismiss the case.

President of the Court
Session Secretary

for the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig>, is based – in essence – on choosing between different alternatives that compete among themselves to regulate a specific matter. It only selects what it deems – according to its assessment – more suitable than others to achieve the objectives it seeks. Whenever the legislative regulation is logically linked to these objectives – and assuming its legality – this regulation is in conformity with the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig>. This Court may not interfere in a matter that is inherently within the work of the legislative authority in this manner, nor weigh with its subjective standards the legislative policy adopted by the legislator on a specific matter, nor discuss it, or delve into the expediency of its practical application, nor evaluate the legislator's choices as long as it has been established that the legislator has exercised its powers, inspired by objectives required by the public interest regarding the subject of the legislative regulation.

Given that, and since the legislator regulated the insurance contract in the Civil Code <orig>القانون المدني</orig> in Articles (773) to (809), the provisions of these articles – as disclosed by the Explanatory Memorandum of the Law – collectively aim to protect the insured. Article (808) thereof did not permit the treatment or amendment of its provisions unless it was in the interest of the insured or the beneficiary. In return, Article (790) of the Law placed obligations on the insured, including clearly stating, at the time of concluding the contract, all known circumstances that are important for the insurer to know in order to assess the risks it undertakes, considering that the insured risk is the essential element in insurance. Article (791) specified the penalty for breaching this obligation if the insured remained silent about a matter or provided incorrect data, and this would change the subject of the risk or reduce its importance in the insurer's view. This penalty was made the contract being voidable in the interest of the insurer, without differentiating between the good-faith insured and the bad-faith insured. However, the second paragraph of the Article limited this penalty to the case where the truth is revealed before the risk materializes, allowing the insurer to request the annulment of the contract ten days after notifying the insured by registered letter, unless the latter accepted an increase in the premium proportionate to the increase in the risk. And in the session of 2023/11/28, the Court of First Instance ruled to dismiss the lawsuit, so the plaintiff appealed its judgment in appeals numbers (3978), (3981), and (4061) for the year 2023, Administrative Contracts and Individual Appeals/4, and argued the unconstitutionality of the challenged decision. In the session of 2024/4/25, the Court of Appeal <orig>محكمة الاستئناف</orig> ruled to suspend consideration of the appeals and refer them to the Constitutional Court <orig>المحكمة الدستورية</orig> to decide on the constitutionality of Articles (1), (2), and (3) of the decision and Table No. (1) attached thereto, regarding their imposition of a fee for the treatment of medical waste, medicines, and medical consumables, in violation of Article (134) of the Constitution. Following the arrival of the case file at the Registry Department <orig>إدارة كتاب</orig> of this Court, it was registered under number (2) for the year 2024 "Constitutional", and the concerned parties were notified accordingly.

In the Name of His Highness the Amir of Kuwait
Sheikh Mishal Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah <orig>الشيخ مشعل الأحمد الجابر الصباح</orig>
### The Constitutional Judgment
In the session held publicly at the Court on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1446 AH, corresponding to 30 April 2025 AD
Presided over by His Excellency Counselor / Adel Ali Al-Bahou <orig>عادل علي البحو</orig>, President of the Court
And with the membership of Their Excellencies Counselors /
Saleh Khalifa Al-Murshed <orig>صالح خليفه المرشد</orig> and Abdul Rahman Mishari Al-Darmi <orig>عبد الرحمن مشاري الدارمي</orig>
and Ibrahim Abdul Rahman Al-Saif <orig>إبراهيم عبد الرحمن السيف</orig> and Waleed Ibrahim Al-Moajel <orig>وليد إبراهيم المعجل</orig>
And in the presence of Mr. / Yousef Ahmed Ma'rafi <orig>يوسف أحمد معرفي</orig>, Session Secretary
The following judgment was issued:
In the lawsuit registered in the Constitutional Court's <orig>المحكمة الدستورية</orig> register under number (2) for the year 2024 "Constitutional"
After the Court of Appeal <orig>محكمة الاستئناف</orig> referred appeals numbers (3978), (3981), and (4061) for the year 2023, Administrative Contracts and Individual Appeals/4, filed by:
Essam Abdul Samad Mohammed Al-Saleh <orig>عصام عبد الصمد محمد الصالح</orig> on his own behalf and in his capacity as Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Union of Private Medical Professions Owners <orig>اتحاد أصحاب المهن الطبية الأهلية</orig>
Against:
1 - The Undersecretary of the Ministry of Health <orig>وزارة الصحة</orig>, in his capacity.
2 - The Prime Minister <orig>رئيس مجلس الوزراء</orig>, in his capacity.
3 - The Secretary-General of the Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>, in his capacity.
4 - The Minister of Health <orig>وزير الصحة</orig>, in his capacity.
### The Facts
Whereas the summary of the facts - as evident from the referral judgment and all other documents - is that the plaintiff (Essam Abdul Samad Mohammed Al-Saleh <orig>عصام عبد الصمد محمد الصالح</orig> on his own behalf and in his capacity) filed lawsuit No. (8080) for the year 2022, Administrative Plenary /6, against the defendants, requesting a judgment to suspend the implementation of Ministerial Decision No. (196) for the year 2022, dated 2022/5/17, to consider it null and void, and to cancel its resulting effects, on the grounds that the Minister of Health <orig>وزير الصحة</orig> issued the aforementioned challenged decision, published in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig> on 2022/5/29, obliging private medical sector institutions to treat medical waste resulting from their operations at the Ministry's medical waste treatment unit and by contracting with the company assigned by it. The decision prohibited granting or renewing health licenses for all private medical sector institutions except after submitting a certificate confirming a contract with that company, and since this decision contradicts the constitutionally protected right to property, and violates the provisions of Law No. (72) for the year 2020 regarding competition protection, by restricting free competition, as well as Law No. (70) for the year 2020 regarding the practice of medicine and allied professions, patient rights, and health facilities, which stipulated in Article (56) thereof that private medical sector institutions must safely dispose of medical waste without limiting this to contracting with a specific company. Furthermore, the decision was flawed due to abuse of authority by setting exorbitant costs for contracting with the company assigned by the Ministry, which would harm the interests of

This Court considered the lawsuit in the session of 2025/2/5, as detailed in its minutes, and the plaintiff appeared in person, and those present with him submitted three memoranda, at the conclusion of which they requested a judgment on the unconstitutionality of the challenged Ministerial Decision. The Fatwa and Legislation Department <orig>إدارة الفتوى والتشريع</orig> submitted a memorandum in defense of the government, requesting at its conclusion a judgment to dismiss the lawsuit, and the Court decided to issue its judgment in it in today's session.
### The Judgment
After reviewing the documents, hearing the pleadings, and deliberation.
Whereas the referral procedures have fulfilled their legally prescribed conditions.
Whereas the challenged Ministerial Decision No. (196) for the year 2022, issued on 2022/5/17 - and published in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig> on 2022/5/29 - stipulates in its Article (1) that: "It is prohibited to grant, issue, or renew health licenses for all types and specializations of healthcare facilities, pharmaceutical factories, warehouses, companies, and pharmacies in the private medical sector, except after submitting a certificate issued by the Hotel Services Department <orig>إدارة الخدمات الفندقية</orig> and approved by the Environmental Audit Department <orig>إدارة التدقيق البيئي</orig> of the Ministry of Health <orig>وزارة الصحة</orig>, confirming a contract with the company assigned to manage, operate, and maintain the Kabad 3 <orig>كبد 3</orig> medical waste treatment plant affiliated with the Ministry of Health <orig>وزارة الصحة</orig> for the treatment of their medical waste, medicines, and medical consumables. A grace period of (30) days is granted after the publication of the decision in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig> for those who obtained a license before the issuance of the decision to submit the certificate."
And Article (2) of the decision stipulates that: "The duration of the medical waste treatment contract for healthcare facilities, pharmaceutical factories, warehouses, companies, and pharmacies in the private medical sector must be the same as the duration granted for the license, according to regulatory and ministerial decisions."
And Article (3) thereof stipulates that: "The cost of treating medical waste, medicines, and medical consumables shall not exceed the maximum limit stipulated in Annex No. 1 attached to the decision."
And Annex No. (1) attached to the aforementioned decision listed the prescribed costs

Rather, it may change according to the nature of transactions in terms of their volume, quantity, or performance circumstances.
Given this, and as the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة</orig> stated that the Ministry of Health <orig>وزارة الصحة</orig> had assigned to one of the private companies – by virtue of the contract it concluded with it after the tender was awarded to it – the tasks of managing, operating, and maintaining its medical waste treatment plant, and based on that, the Minister of Health <orig>وزير الصحة</orig> issued the challenged Ministerial Decision <orig>القرار الوزاري المطعون فيه</orig>, which prohibited the granting, issuance, or renewal of health licenses for all types and specializations of healthcare facilities, as well as pharmaceutical factories, warehouses, companies, and pharmacies in the private medical sector, except after submitting a certificate from the competent department confirming a contract with that company for the treatment of their medical waste, medicines, and medical consumables, provided that the contract duration is the same as the duration granted for the license. It was also stipulated that the cost of treating medical waste, medicines, and medical consumables agreed upon in that contract shall not exceed the maximum limit stated in the annex attached to the decision. Therefore, what the decision contained regarding the cost of treating the aforementioned waste is not considered a fee, as it is not a fixed amount that all health facilities are obligated to pay, but rather it is estimated according to purely economic considerations that take into account the nature and quantity of the waste to be treated. The true nature of this cost, as for the service requested by the medical facility from the company assigned by the Ministry of Health <orig>وزارة الصحة</orig> to manage a plant for treating its waste, does not fall within the concept of fees, which can only be established within the limits of the law. Furthermore, the challenged decision did not impose a specific charge on health facilities that they are obligated to pay to that company, but rather set an upper limit that cannot be exceeded in the contract concluded between the two parties. Consequently, the claim that the challenged decision imposed a fee on health facilities in violation of Article (134) of the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig> is unfounded, and therefore, the court must rule to dismiss the case.
Whereas it is established – in the jurisprudence of this Court – that the scope of a constitutional case is determined by the scope of the plea of unconstitutionality raised before the trial court, and within the limits in which that court assesses its seriousness. Therefore, the Court disregards the reasons for the plea of unconstitutionality of the challenged decision presented by the plaintiff in his memoranda, and confines itself to what the trial court stated as an objection to that decision in the referral judgment, without exceeding that scope.
Whereas the basis of the objection to the aforementioned articles of the challenged Ministerial Decision <orig>قرار وزير الصحة المطعون فيه</orig> and its attached schedule – as evident from the referral judgment – is that the correct classification of the amounts listed in the schedule attached to the challenged decision is that they are, in reality, a fee prescribed for benefiting from the services of the medical waste treatment unit resulting from the private medical sector. And that the decision, by doing so, has imposed a fee for the treatment of medical waste, medicines, and medical consumables in violation of Article (134) of the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig>, which does not permit the imposition of fees except within the limits of the law, meaning that the government's authority to impose fees can only be through a law that authorizes it to exercise this authority, otherwise its imposition would be unconstitutional.
Whereas this objection is refutable, as the import of Article (134) of the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig> is that no one may be charged with paying fees except within the limits of the law. Fees are defined as what a public entity imposes in exchange for specific services it provides to those who request them, and their estimation does not consider the cost of the service, as their amount is generally fixed for all beneficiaries of these services, throughout the validity of the legislative instrument that imposed them. In this way, they differ from the price or service charge collected by entities responsible for managing state property, as this price or charge is paid to an economic facility managed by an entity according to economic management methods, and it is determined according to purely economic criteria. It is subject to changes imposed by the nature of economic conditions and may accommodate changes resulting from negotiations between the product or service requester and the economic facility.

For these reasons
The Court ruled: to dismiss the case.
Session Secretary
Presiding Judge

Whereas it is established – in the jurisprudence of this Court – that litigation in a direct constitutional challenge, like all constitutional litigations, is an in rem litigation primarily directed at the legislative text challenged for unconstitutionality. Its basis is to challenge that text itself, aiming to monitor it and verify the extent of its conformity with the Constitution. The legislative text, in this regard, is the subject and object of the litigation, to which it pertains and by whose scope it is defined.
And whereas this Court, in its session held on 2025/2/5, ruled in Challenge No. (5) of 2023, a "direct constitutional challenge," "on the unconstitutionality of Clause (1) of Article (34) of Law No. (72) of 2020 concerning Competition Protection <orig>حماية المنافسة</orig>, in what it included regarding the imposition of financial penalties not exceeding ten percent (10%) of the total revenues achieved by the concerned person during the preceding fiscal year in case of violating the provisions of Articles (5), (6), (7), and (8) of this Law." And since the present challenge by the appellant was directed at the same aforementioned article, aiming for a ruling on its unconstitutionality, the litigation in this challenge consequently becomes moot, as its subject matter has ceased to exist and its cause has vanished, with that judgment fulfilling the appellant's requests. As for the challenge against the articles of the executive regulations related to the implementation of financial penalties, it has also become moot after the disappearance of the text that stipulates these penalties. Therefore, the constitutional litigation in this challenge – as is the case – is terminated, which must be declared.

Therefore,
The Court – in the Consultative Chamber <orig>غرفة المشورة</orig> – decided the termination of the litigation in the challenge.

Secretary
President of the Court

# The Constitutional Court <orig>المحكمة الدستورية</orig>
## Consultative Chamber <orig>غرفة المشورة</orig>
At the session held by the Court in the Consultative Chamber <orig>غرفة المشورة</orig> on 2 Dhul-Qa'dah <orig>ذو القعدة</orig> 1446 AH, corresponding to 30 April 2025 AD
Presided over by His Excellency Counselor <orig>المستشار</orig> / Adel Ali Al-Bahwa <orig>عادل علي البحوه</orig>, President of the Court
And with the membership of Their Excellencies Counselors <orig>المستشارين</orig>:
Saleh Khalifa Al-Murshed <orig>صالح خليفه المرشد</orig> and Abdul Rahman Mishari Al-Darmi <orig>عبد الرحمن مشاري الدارمي</orig>
and Ibrahim Abdul Rahman Al-Saif <orig>إبراهيم عبد الرحمن السيف</orig> and Waleed Ibrahim Al-Moajel <orig>وليد إبراهيم المعجل</orig>
And in the presence of Mr. / Yousef Ahmed Ma'rafi <orig>يوسف أحمد معرفي</orig>, Secretary of the Session
The following decision was issued:
In the Direct Challenge / Consultative Chamber <orig>غرفة المشورة</orig>
Registered in the Court's register under No. (13) of 2024
Filed by:
The legal representative of Al-Muzaini Exchange Company <orig>شركة المزيني للصيرفة</orig>
The Court
After reviewing the documents and deliberation.
Whereas the appellant company challenged the unconstitutionality of Article (34), Clause (1) of Law No. (72) of 2020 concerning Competition Protection <orig>حماية المنافسة</orig>, and Articles (48), (49), and (50) of Decision No. (14) of 2021 regarding the issuance of the Executive Regulations of the Law. The appellant argued that Article (34), Clause (1) of the Law overlooked the principle of proportionality between the violation and the penalty or sanction prescribed for it, as imposing a financial penalty on the violating person at a rate not exceeding (10%) of the total revenues achieved during the fiscal year preceding the violation represents a financial penalty characterized by exaggeration, excessiveness, and disproportionality with the committed violation and its resulting effects. There is no connection between it and the activity for which the violation was committed, as it extends to include all revenues of the violator, regardless of their relation to that violation, which unequivocally demonstrates the harshness and excessiveness of this financial penalty and its incompatibility with justice. Furthermore, this article also violated the principle of equality by allowing the Disciplinary Council <orig>مجلس التأديب</orig> to impose different financial penalties on perpetrators of the same violation, in contravention of Articles (7), (8), and (29) of the Constitution. As for the challenged articles of the Executive Regulations, they made the decisions of the Disciplinary Council <orig>مجلس التأديب</orig> enforceable immediately upon their issuance, and in case of non-compliance, the Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Authority <orig>الجهاز</orig> shall submit a report to the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> in this regard, despite the Law not containing such provisions, thus creating new offenses

Whereas the appellant company <orig>الشركة الطاعنة</orig> challenged the unconstitutionality of Article (34), paragraph (1) of Law No. (72) of 2020 regarding Competition Protection <orig>قانون حماية المنافسة</orig>, and Articles (48), (49), and (50) of Resolution No. (14) of 2021 regarding the Issuance of the Executive Regulations of the Law <orig>اللائحة التنفيذية للقانون</orig>, arguing that Article (34), paragraph (1) of the Law violated the principle of proportionality between the violation and the penalty or sanction prescribed for it. This is because imposing a financial penalty on the violating person at a rate not exceeding (10%) of the total revenues achieved during the fiscal year preceding the violation represents a financial penalty characterized by exaggeration, excessiveness, and disproportionality with the committed violation and its resulting effects. Furthermore, there is no link between it and the activity for which the violation was committed, as it extends to include all revenues of the violator, regardless of their relation to that violation, which unequivocally demonstrates the harshness, excessiveness, and injustice of this financial penalty. Moreover, this article also violated the principle of equality, as it allowed the Disciplinary Council <orig>مجلس التأديب</orig> to impose different financial penalties on perpetrators of the same violation, in contravention of Articles (7), (8), and (29) of the Constitution. As for the challenged articles of the Executive Regulations, they made the decisions of the Disciplinary Council <orig>مجلس التأديب</orig> immediately enforceable upon their issuance, and in case of non-compliance, the Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Authority <orig>رئيس مجلس إدارة الجهاز</orig> submits a report to the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> in this regard, despite the Law not including such provisions. Thus, these regulations introduced crimes not stipulated in the Law, in contravention of Article (32) of the Constitution. The appeal had a direct personal interest in submitting its present appeal, as Disciplinary Council <orig>مجلس التأديب</orig> Decision No. (3) of 2024 was issued on 2024/7/10, fining it by (5%) of the total revenues it achieved during the previous fiscal year, for violating Article (5) of the aforementioned Law No. (72) of 2020, which prompted it to submit its present appeal.

Whereas it is established – in the jurisprudence of this Court – that litigation in a direct appeal, like all constitutional litigations, is an objective litigation <orig>خصومة عينية</orig> primarily directed at the legislative text challenged for unconstitutionality. Its basis is the competence of that text itself, aiming to monitor it and verify the extent of its conformity with the Constitution. The legislative text, in this regard, is the subject matter and locus of the litigation, to which it pertains and by whose scope it is defined.
And whereas this Court ruled in its sessions held on 2025/2/5 in Appeal No. (5) of 2023, a "Direct Constitutional Appeal" <orig>طعن مباشر دستوري</orig>, "on the unconstitutionality of paragraph (1) of Article (34) of Law No. (72) of 2020 regarding Competition Protection <orig>قانون حماية المنافسة</orig>, insofar as it included the imposition of financial penalties at a rate not exceeding ten percent (10%) of the total revenues achieved by the concerned person during the previous fiscal year in case of violating the provisions of Articles Nos. (5), (6), (7), and (8) of this Law." And since the present appeal focused on the same aforementioned article, aiming for a ruling on its unconstitutionality, the litigation in this appeal consequently becomes moot <orig>غير ذات موضوع</orig> as a result, after its subject matter ceased to exist and its cause vanished, leading that judgment to fulfill the appellant's requests. As for the challenge to the articles of the Executive Regulations related to the implementation of financial penalties, they also became without merit <orig>لا محل لها</orig> after the disappearance of the text that stipulates these penalties. Therefore, the constitutional litigation in the appeal – under these circumstances – is terminated, which must be declared.

## Therefore
**The Court, in chambers, decided the termination of the litigation in the appeal.**
Court Secretary **Chief Justice**

During the consideration of the case in the sessions, the appellant submitted a memorandum arguing the unconstitutionality of what is stipulated in Article (125) of Law No. (7) of 2010, which penalizes "any person who falsely claims that the Authority has taken any measure or decision that it has not actually taken," due to the failure to definitively specify the criminalized acts, which prevents their confusion with others, in violation of Articles (30), (32), and (36) of the Constitution.
In the session of 16/9/2024, the Misdemeanor Court of the Capital Market <orig>سوق المال</orig> ruled that the plea of unconstitutionality was not serious, and penalized the appellant by fining him an amount of five thousand Kuwaiti Dinars <orig>دينار كويتي</orig> for the accusation attributed to him.
As the appellant was not satisfied with the ruling of the latter judgment regarding its finding that the plea of unconstitutionality was not serious, he appealed it before the Appeals Examination Committee <orig>لجنة فحص الطعون</orig> of the Constitutional Court <orig>المحكمة الدستورية</orig> with a petition filed with the Registry Department <orig>إدارة كتاب</orig> of this Court on 13/10/2024, where it was registered under No. (7) of 2024 "Appeals Examination Committee." At the conclusion of that petition, he requested the annulment of the judgment issued finding the plea of unconstitutionality not serious, and the referral of the matter to the Constitutional Court <orig>المحكمة الدستورية</orig> – in its full composition – for a decision.
This Court considered the appeal in the session of 5/2/2025, as indicated in the session minutes. The appellant appeared in person, submitted a portfolio of documents, and insisted on his requests contained in the appeal petition. The representative of the Capital Markets Authority <orig>هيئة أسواق المال</orig> submitted a memorandum requesting at its conclusion a judgment rejecting the appeal. The representative of the Fatwa and Legislation Department <orig>إدارة الفتوى والتشريع</orig> submitted a memorandum requesting at its conclusion, primarily, a judgment of inadmissibility of the appeal, and alternatively, its rejection. The Court decided to issue its judgment on the appeal in today's session.

### The Rationale
After reviewing the documents, hearing the pleadings, and deliberation.
Whereas the appeal has fulfilled its legally prescribed conditions.
Whereas the appellant faults the appealed judgment for insufficiency of reasoning and corruption in inference, as it ruled on the unconstitutionality of the clause to the extent it generally included what is stipulated in Article (125) of Law No. (7) of 2010 regarding the penalization of "any person who falsely claims that the Authority has taken any measure or decision that it has not actually taken," despite it being tainted by suspicion of unconstitutionality due to the failure to definitively specify the criminalized acts, which prevents their confusion with others, in violation of Articles (30), (32), and (36) of the Constitution.
Whereas this objection is rebutted by what is established – in the jurisprudence of this Court – that the assessment of the seriousness of the plea of unconstitutionality requires the convergence of two necessary conditions: first, that the decision on the constitutional matter is necessary for deciding the substantive dispute; and second, that there is an apparent suspicion of the legislative text, subject of the plea, violating the provisions of the Constitution.
Given this, and since the legislator, by virtue of the challenged text in the aforementioned Law No. (7) of 2010, penalized "any person who falsely claims that the Authority has taken any measure or decision that it has not actually taken," the text was clear in defining the material element required for this crime, which is the performance of a positive act consisting of claiming that the Capital Markets Authority <orig>هيئة أسواق المال</orig> has taken a measure or decision related to its activities exercised in accordance with the provisions of this law, and that it is proven that it did not actually take this measure or decision; if it had indeed taken it, the material element of the crime would not be fulfilled. And since this crime is an intentional crime, this act must be accompanied by criminal intent, which is the perpetrator's will and intention to alter the truth by attributing actions to the Authority that it did not perform, with his knowledge thereof. The burden of proof for the existence of the crime with its elements, as previously stated, lies with the prosecution authority, and the Court is obligated to verify this itself in light of its assessment of the evidence presented to it. Consequently, the objection to the challenged text regarding the lack of clarity and definition of the criminalized acts, which could lead to their confusion with other acts, is a claim not based on a sound premise. And since the appealed judgment concluded that the plea of unconstitutionality was not serious, it has reached a correct conclusion, and the appeal against it is therefore not based on a sound foundation, and thus it must be ruled to be rejected, and the appellant ordered to pay the costs.

### For These Reasons
The Court ruled: to accept the appeal formally, and reject it substantively, and ordered the appellant to pay the costs.
Session Secretary / Court President
<page_end>233</page_end>

and his undertaking to commit to repaying the outstanding debt to the Bank, for which these banking facilities were granted, and based on this, or in good faith, fictitiously in the Company, by virtue of Official Amendment Contract No. 3195/2019 <orig>٣١٩٥ / ٢٠١٩</orig> dated 22/9/2019. However, this partner failed to fulfill his undertaking to repay the value of the banking facilities and caused the applicant company's interests to be disrupted and involved it in legal disputes. Thus, a clear divergence from its anomaly was warranted, and this partner caused the actual owner and manager of the company, Mr. Ibrahim Abdul Nabi Al-Shirazi <orig>إبراهيم عبد النبي الشيرازي</orig>, to be removed by a judicial instrument, which led to the removal of the manager's authority from the company's management and the cessation of its operations and activities. In a serious attempt by the company to salvage the situation with the fictitious companies in order to manage the company's affairs and fulfill its obligations towards third parties, an agreement was reached with him by virtue of an official agreement contract dated 3/1/2021, in which he undertook to be the fourth party responsible for repaying the loan due to the aforementioned Bank (the Banking Facilities Contract). The contract was submitted in one of the dismissed lawsuits by virtue of the agreement's enforceability in Case No. 2056/2020 <orig>٢٠٥٦ / ٢٠٢٠</orig> Commercial Plenary. Based on this judgment, the applicant company sent a letter to the Bank to present its guarantee bond from Mr. Hassan Ali Mohammed Hajja <orig>حسن علي محمد حاجة</orig>, confirming his assumption of the debt and his undertaking to repay it. The aforementioned Bank accepted these interests, but the aforementioned individual did not adhere to what he undertook in the settlement agreement. After its suffering with the fictitious partner, the Court of Cassation <orig>محكمة التمييز</orig> ruled on 14/6/2023 in Appeal No. 2333/2023 <orig>٢٣٣٣ / ٢٠٢٣</orig> Commercial, regarding the fictitious nature of the official company amendment contract documented under No. 3195/2019 <orig>٣١٩٥ / ٢٠١٩</orig>, which is the company amendment contract by virtue of which this fictitious partner joined the applicant company. This judgment heralds the return of the applicant company to its former state of conducting its activities and fulfilling all its obligations, which prompted it to approach the aforementioned Bank to conduct an amicable settlement regarding the outstanding debt by virtue of the assignment of debt that the aforementioned Bank accepted and which is still pending before the judiciary. However, the aforementioned Bank did not facilitate the loyal parties in that lawsuit and proceeded to take enforcement actions against the guarantors, especially Arkan Financial Company (Business) / Arkan Al-Maliya (A'mal) <orig>أركان المالية (أعمال)</orig>.

<header>
Kuwait Today / Al-Kuwait Al-Youm <orig>الكويت اليوم</orig> Issue No. 1738 Seventy-First Year 245

# Amendment to Some Provisions of the Bankruptcy Law
## Presented Facts

Based on the foregoing work by the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig>, the papers were presented for disposition, and a decision was issued in accordance with the presented facts.

Whereas it is stipulated in the first paragraph of Article 81 of the Bankruptcy Law <orig>قانون الإفلاس</orig> issued by Law No. 71 of 2020 that: "The debtor <orig>المدين</orig> must, within ten days from the date of approval or rejection of the preventive settlement proposal <orig>مقترح التسوية الوقائية</orig>, notify the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig>, the Supervisor <orig>المراقب</orig>, the Bankruptcy Authority <orig>هيئة الإفلاس</orig>, and the Financial Regulatory Interface <orig>واجهة الرقابة المالية</orig> – as the case may be – of this, attaching the approved or rejected plan, the minutes of the meetings in which the voting took place, any documentation indicating the objections raised, meeting attendance, proof of attendance, and proof of voting. In case of approval of the plan, ratification of the plan must be requested within the notification."

It is also stipulated in Article 82 of the Bankruptcy Law <orig>قانون الإفلاس</orig> that: "The Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> shall, within ten days from the date the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> receives the notification of the creditors' approval of the preventive settlement proposal <orig>مقترح التسوية الوقائية</orig> and its attachments, ratify the proposal after verifying the fulfillment of the following two conditions: 1- That the proposal has obtained the required majority approval. 2- That the proposal meets the criteria of fairness for the affected creditors <orig>الدائنين المتأثرين</orig>."

It is also stipulated in Article 86 of the Bankruptcy Law <orig>قانون الإفلاس</orig> that: "The preventive settlement proposal <orig>مقترح التسوية الوقائية</orig> ratified by the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> shall be enforceable against all creditors <orig>الدائنين</orig> covered by it, including those creditors who rejected the proposal and those who did not attend the meeting for voting on the proposal. The Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> shall carry out announcement, publication, notification, disclosure, and registration in accordance with Article (33) of this Law for every decision issued regarding the ratification of the preventive settlement proposal <orig>مقترح التسوية الوقائية</orig>, or the rejection of the proposal, or the suspension of ratification, or the cancellation of procedures, or the commencement of restructuring procedures <orig>إجراءات إعادة الهيكلة</orig>, or the declaration of bankruptcy <orig>شهر الإفلاس</orig>, within ten days from the date of the decision's issuance. The Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> may suffice with registering the decision in the Bankruptcy Register <orig>سجل الإفلاس</orig> and the Commercial Register <orig>السجل التجاري</orig>."

And by Article (87) of the same Law, it is stipulated that: "The debtor <orig>المدين</orig> is obligated to implement the preventive settlement proposal <orig>مقترح التسوية الوقائية</orig> in accordance with what the creditors <orig>الدائنون</orig> approved and the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> ratified. He is also obligated, within ten days from the date of undertaking the settlement proposal, to notify the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> of this, attaching to the notification a statement of the debts that have been settled and the method of settlement, as well as attaching the document proving the settlement. The Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> shall issue a decision to that effect. In the event that the debtor <orig>المدين</orig> fails to implement the preventive settlement proposal <orig>مقترح التسوية الوقائية</orig> in accordance with what the creditors <orig>الدائنون</orig> approved and the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> ratified, or in the event that the debtor fails to notify the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> of this, or in the event that the debtor fails to submit the document proving the settlement, the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> may issue a decision to cancel the preventive settlement proposal <orig>مقترح التسوية الوقائية</orig>, or issue a decision to commence restructuring procedures <orig>إجراءات إعادة الهيكلة</orig>, or issue a decision to declare bankruptcy <orig>شهر الإفلاس</orig>. This shall be after hearing the statements of the debtor <orig>المدين</orig>, the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig>, and the Supervisor <orig>المراقب</orig>, and after verifying the fulfillment of the conditions for canceling the preventive settlement proposal <orig>مقترح التسوية الوقائية</orig>, or commencing restructuring procedures <orig>إجراءات إعادة الهيكلة</orig>, or declaring bankruptcy <orig>شهر الإفلاس</orig>."
<page_end>245</page_end>

completion of the implementation of the settlement proposal and termination of preventive settlement procedures within ten days from the date the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> receives the notification. The second paragraph of Article (86) of this Law applies to the decision. The Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> may request the opinion of the supervisor, if appointed, regarding the completion of the settlement implementation before issuing the aforementioned decision. He may also request the opinion of the Bankruptcy Committee <orig>لجنة الإفلاس</orig> regarding the completion of the settlement implementation, even if the indebtedness is not subject to its supervision, before issuing the aforementioned decision.
Debtors who challenge the validity of what is stated in the debtor's notification regarding the settlement of their indebtedness may appeal the decision referred to in the preceding paragraph. If the request is accepted, the debtor is obligated to implement the preventive settlement proposal, guaranteed by the debtor who accepted its submission, and the preventive settlement proposal and its terms <orig>عقيده</orig> shall apply to this creditor.
In light of the foregoing and proceeding therewith, the applicant company <orig>الشركة الطالبة</orig> had submitted its current request to the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> to initiate preventive settlement procedures against the creditor bank <orig>البنك المتقدم</orig> regarding its indebtedness for which the request was submitted. After it submitted a memorandum containing a brief description of its economic and financial situation and information about its assets, supported by documents accompanying the request, and the opinion of the Bankruptcy Committee <orig>لجنة الإفلاس</orig> was taken, approved by its decision in Report No. (2023/8) dated 11/9/2023, which concluded that, according to the available documents, the applicant company's situation indicates the possibility of continuing its operations and its ability to pay its outstanding debts if the preventive settlement is accepted, the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> issued a decision on 17/9/2023 to initiate preventive settlement procedures. The applicant company, after the issuance of the decision to initiate procedures, deposited a copy of the preventive settlement proposal with the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> and proceeded, during the period of suspension of ordinary claims, to persuade the creditor bank <orig>البنك المتقدم ضده</orig> to agree to the settlement proposal. It attached to the request a letter from the creditor bank <orig>البنك المتقدم ضده</orig> dated 5/2/2024 approving the preventive settlement proposal. A representative of the creditor bank <orig>البنك المتقدم ضده</orig> attended the session on 7/3/2024 and confirmed the bank's approval of that proposal and the payment of the settlement amount according to the method referred to in the said letter. The applicant company had no creditors - as per the documents on file - other than the bank against which the claim was filed regarding the indebtedness in question. Therefore, the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> issued a decision on 10/3/2024 to ratify the preventive settlement proposal, including what was agreed upon between its parties and endorsed by the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig>, for the applicant company <orig>الشركة الطالبة</orig> to pay an amount of KWD 2,520,000.

## Therefore

## We have ruled as follows -

By completing the implementation of the settlement proposal and terminating the preventive settlement procedures, and the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> shall notify the Central Bank <orig>البنك المركزي</orig>, the General Department of Execution <orig>الإدارة العامة للتنفيذ</orig>, the Real Estate Registration Department <orig>إدارة التسجيل العقاري</orig>, Kuwait Municipality <orig>بلدية الكويت</orig>, the applicant company, the bank against which the application was filed, and also this bankruptcy of this decision, along with its registration in the Bankruptcy Register <orig>سجل الإفلاس</orig> and the Commercial Register <orig>السجل التجاري</orig> and its publication in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>, while obligating the applicant company to pay the fee.

Upon reviewing the application,
the facts of the application summarize that the first applicant, I.M. Sweets and Confectionery Company <orig>شركة ايه ام للحلويات والمعجنات</orig>, a limited liability company, and the second applicant, Anwar Bader Hassan Mohammed <orig>انوار بدر حسن محمد</orig>, are companies listed among small and medium-sized enterprises, owning the largest share in the debtor company. It was stated that the first applicant's situation arose during the COVID-19 pandemic, which impacted its sales and led to its financial distress, without a clear record of its payments to some of its creditors. The second applicant, Anwar Bader Hassan Mohammed <orig>انوار بدر حسن محمد</orig>, initiated debt restructuring. Both the first and second applicants requested the restructuring of their debts. The debtor company, which is a responsible company, requested a statement of insurance and the preparation of a company budget for the year 2021-2022, along with copies of debt certificates, which were reviewed.

## Legal Text:

Whereas it is stipulated in the text of Articles (1-33-29-25-97-34-03-102-290) of Bankruptcy Law No. 71/2020, regarding the applicability of this law, the following words and phrases shall have the meaning specified opposite each of them: claims shall cease, suspending any lawsuit or judicial proceeding initiated against the debtor, whenever it relates to their assets or properties. The special debts under the supervision of the Bankruptcy Committee <orig>لجنة الإفلاس</orig> are the debts of companies listed on the stock exchange and any other debts that the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> assigns the Committee to supervise. The Bankruptcy Committee <orig>لجنة الإفلاس</orig> shall, within ten days from the date of its notification of the request – after which the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> shall set a shorter or longer period for the submission of all debts related to bankruptcy liabilities and the submission of a report to the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> concerning it, which shall include the following matters:
1- The possibility of preventive settlement or restructuring, or the lack thereof.
3- Whether urgent precautionary measures should be taken, or not, and the progress of such
4- Whether the debtor is capable of managing their own business and assets.
5- Whether precautionary measures should be taken that would terminate the specified period during which a decision must be issued to commence preventive settlement or restructuring procedures...". And the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig>, upon a request submitted to him by the debtor, may issue a decision to suspend the procedures. The issuance of a decision to commence restructuring procedures results in the suspension of claims starting from the day following the date of this decision until the date of approval of the restructuring plan, and the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> shall hand over to the debtor, upon their request, the suspension of these
approval of the restructuring plan, and the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> shall hand over to the debtor, upon their request, the suspension of these

It was decided
### Article (1)
A central committee, known as the "Central Committee for Price Study, Inflation Monitoring, and Supply Chains," shall be formed within the Ministry of Commerce and Industry <orig>وزارة التجارة والصناعة</orig>, chaired by the Undersecretary of the Ministry of Commerce and Industry <orig>وكيل وزارة التجارة والصناعة</orig>. The committee shall include, as members, representatives (at a rank not less than a department director or equivalent) from the following entities:
1. A representative from the Ministry of Commerce and Industry <orig>وزارة التجارة والصناعة</orig>.
2. A representative from the Ministry of Social Affairs, Family and Childhood Affairs <orig>وزارة الشؤون الاجتماعية وشؤون الأسرة والطفولة</orig>.
3. A representative from Kuwait University <orig>جامعة الكويت</orig>.
4. A representative from the Union of Cooperative Societies <orig>اتحاد الجمعيات التعاونية</orig>.
5. A representative from the Kuwait Institute for Scientific Research <orig>معهد الكويت للأبحاث العلمية</orig>.
6. A representative from the Public Authority for Food and Nutrition <orig>الهيئة العامة للغذاء والتغذية</orig>.
7. A representative from the General Administration of Customs <orig>الإدارة العامة للجمارك</orig>.
8. A representative from the General Fire Force <orig>قوة الإطفاء العام</orig>.
9. A representative from the Kuwait Supply Company <orig>الشركة الكويتية للتموين</orig>.
10. A representative from the Competition Protection Agency <orig>جهاز حماية المنافسة</orig>.
11. A representative from the Consumer Protection Society <orig>جمعية حماية المستهلك</orig>.
12. A representative from the Central Statistical Bureau <orig>الإدارة المركزية للإحصاء</orig>.
13. A representative from the Kuwaiti Union of Poultry Producers <orig>الاتحاد الكويتي لمنتجي الدواجن</orig>.
14. A representative from the Union of Distributors of Consumer Goods for Wholesale and Retail Trade <orig>اتحاد موزعي المواد الاستهلاكية لتجارة الجملة والتجزئة</orig>.
15. A representative from the Kuwaiti Union of Food Traders and Manufacturers <orig>الاتحاد الكويتي لتجار ومصنعي المواد الغذائية</orig>.
The committee may, when necessary, seek assistance from experts and specialists, provided they do not have the right to vote.
### Article (2)
#### Mandate of the Central Committee
The Central Committee shall be responsible for the following tasks: –
1- Monitoring and determining prices in various markets across the country, and establishing controls and mechanisms to ensure their stability.
2- Studying local inflation rates and proposing appropriate recommendations to address them and mitigate their effects.
3- Monitoring supply chains to ensure their robustness and efficiency, and submitting proposals that contribute to ensuring the regular flow of goods and services.
<page_end>259</page_end>
